story:
Short Summary

Contributors fund ideas they can be passionate about and to people they trust. Here are some things to do in this section:

  • Introduce yourself and your background.
  • Briefly describe your campaign and why it's important to you.
  • Express the magnitude of what contributors will help you achieve.

Remember, keep it concise, yet personal. Ask yourself: if someone stopped reading here would they be ready to make a contribution?

What We Need & What You Get

Break it down for folks in more detail:

  • Explain how much funding you need and where it's going. Be transparent and specific-people need to trust you to want to fund you.
  • Tell people about your unique perks. Get them excited!
  • Describe where the funds go if you don't reach your entire goal.

The Impact

Feel free to explain more about your campaign and let people know the difference their contribution will make:

  • Explain why your project is valuable to the contributor and to the world.
  • Point out your successful track record with projects like this (if you have one).
  • Make it real for people and build trust.

Risks & Challenges

People value your transparency. Be open and stand out by providing insight into the risks and obstacles you may face on the way to achieving your goal.

  • Share what qualifies you to overcome these hurdles.
  • Describe your plan for solving these challenges.

Other Ways You Can Help

Some people just can't contribute, but that doesn't mean they can't help:

  • Ask folks to get the word out and make some noise about your campaign.
  • Remind them to use the Indiegogo share tools!

And that's all there is to it.
story_txt: Short Summary Contributors fund ideas they can be passionate about and to people they trust. Here are some things to do in this section:  Introduce yourself and your background. Briefly describe your campaign and why it's important to you. Express the magnitude of what contributors will help you achieve.  Remember, keep it concise, yet personal. Ask yourself: if someone stopped reading here would they be ready to make a contribution?   What We Need & What You Get Break it down for folks in more detail:  Explain how much funding you need and where it's going. Be transparent and specific-people need to trust you to want to fund you.  Tell people about your unique perks. Get them excited! Describe where the funds go if you don't reach your entire goal.    The Impact Feel free to explain more about your campaign and let people know the difference their contribution will make:  Explain why your project is valuable to the contributor and to the world. Point out your successful track record with projects like this (if you have one). Make it real for people and build trust.    Risks & Challenges  People value your transparency. Be open and stand out by providing insight into the risks and obstacles you may face on the way to achieving your goal.  Share what qualifies you to overcome these hurdles. Describe your plan for solving these challenges.    Other Ways You Can Help Some people just can't contribute, but that doesn't mean they can't help:  Ask folks to get the word out and make some noise about your campaign. Remind them to use the Indiegogo share tools!   And that's all there is to it.

story:
In the fall of 2015, I began the journey of creating my first full length album, “A Home to Run to.” I am proud to announce now, almost a year later, the album is finished. I am incredibly proud of these songs and the album as a whole. I wrote the songs, produced them, and recorded each instrument on the album. The songs are so much bigger and more intricate than anything I’ve attempted before, and I’m incredibly proud of each one of them. That being said, I’ve now come to the end of the road of what I can do, and it’s time to hand the album off to be professionally mixed and mastered (an experience I’ve never had before)! But, being the poor college student that I am, I can’t afford that. So here’s where you come in.

I need your help to fund the mixing and mastering of this album. It is being mixed by Lynn Grabber in Nashville, and mastered by Grammy award winning engineer Andrew Bergthold. This album is so much bigger than the two EPs I’ve released so far. I am proud of those projects as well, and they have given me a great vision of what I want in my sound. This album is just that. Not only am I excited about the sound of this album, I’m excited about the message that these songs will bring. Whether it’s reminiscing on fun summer memories, or coping with insecurities and finding strength outside ourselves, these songs have messages we can all relate to. These songs have been very meaningful and personal to me, and I genuinely hope that listeners find meaning in them as well.

I would love to have your support in completing this album. This has been an amazing journey, and I invite you join along with me in seeing it through to the end!

story:
Hi everyone!

My name is Dr. Jesse Cook. I am the Assistant Professor of Trumpet at Valdosta State University.

            I am in the final stages of preparation for my inaugural CD release, Imagined Conversations: American Music for Trumpet. The album will feature solo trumpet music by composers John Williams, Libby Larsen, Michael Djupstrum, Zack Stanton and David Sterrett. This music is, in my opinion, some of the best trumpet writing done in the past 20 years, yet none have been recorded with the piano reduction - as they’d be performed in competition or recital. All of these pieces are wonderful additions to the trumpet repertoire, and I believe, are worthy of being recorded.

            As many of you know, producing a full-length commercial CD is an expensive and exhaustive process. In order to make this recording, I need to raise $4,250 in the next month, which breaks down to 150 backers donating $30 each. These funds will cover the rental cost for Legacy Hall in Columbus, GA, partially cover MSR Record Label, the cost of tuning the piano in the hall, mechanical rights, and materials for the actual CD production.

Works To Be Recorded:

            I have long been a proponent for expanding the repertoire and reach of the trumpet. In that vein, I asked Zack Stanton, Lecturer in Music Theory and Composition at the University of Iowa, to compose a piece which could be used in graduate student and professional level national solo competitions. Dr. Stanton’s Imagined Conversations, A Sonata for Trumpet and Piano was premiered at Valdosta State University on August 31, 2017. The seminal recording of this work will give greater exposure to this excellent young American composer and aid in promotion of the piece.

            John Williams’ Concerto for Trumpet and Piano was commissioned by the Cleveland Orchestra in 1996. The piano reduction was released the following year; the piece has since been a mainstay on the competition circuit. When performed in competition, the concerto is always presented in the piano reduction. However, there are no commercial recordings of this version; the lack of a quality reference recording has produced many unsuccessful competition performances by trumpet artists who have never heard the work performed. Inclusion of this piece on the CD aims to fix this issue. A recording of this landmark composition in the trumpet repertoire will aid students and professionals around the globe.

            I performed Michael Djupstrum’s Puck three times in recital in fall 2016, and learned that it is popular among non-expert audiences and increases interest in the classical trumpet field. Puck is not a known work but has the potential to become a standard competition piece. Although the piece was originally composed for trumpet and string orchestra the piano reduction demands technical mastery and musicality from both the soloist and pianist. However, the piano reduction keeps intact the string colors through the use of extended techniques (secondary uses) on the instrument. This creates an unusual tonal palette throughout the piece not often found in piano reductions.

            David Sterrett is a freelance trumpet artist and composer in the Dallas/Ft. Worth area. He wrote Rhapsody for his own masters’ degree recital at the New England Conservatory of Music in Boston and the piece has unfailingly received rave reviews from students and professionals. Rhapsody is freely structured with near improvisatory sections and luxurious melodic lines. I performed this work at the 2017 International Trumpet Guild Conference in Hershey, PA. The performance and composition received rave reviews. In my opinion, a quality recording of Rhapsody will likely lead to high demand across the trumpet community nationwide.

            Libby Larsen is one of the foremost American composers of the late 20th and early 21st centuries. Ridge-Runner, though widely appreciated, is rarely performed due to its unusual scoring for trumpet and two percussionists. I believe inclusion of Ridge-Runner will round out the CD artistically with the contrasting tonal palettes offered by the multiple percussionists as well as serve the wider musical community with the first reference recording for the piece.

            I hope you make the choice to support my inaugural CD, and help grow the repertoire of the trumpet as well!

story:
Short Summary

Hi! I'm Sita Rose. I chant. I sing. I create and inspire others to do the same. I am gifted at guiding people to access the full range of their voice for creative expression, energetic release, and spiritual integration. When we connect to our creativity, we connect to our life force. But so often self-judgment and fear interrupt this process and we experience energetic blocks or dis-ease. The idea for my album, In Essence, is a direct result of my work as a board-certified music therapist, yoga student, and Kirtan leader. 

I wanted to create an album that serves as a point of reference for anyone who wants to take command of their voice. Permission that you no longer need permission to sing and experience its benefits. I wanted to create a tool to accompany the journey of self-discovery. This album is more than just music, it’s a launch pad for creativity, inner harmony, and catalyst for healing. Each track is Divinely inspired, reflecting the “essence” of each Chakra.

Somewhere along the way, singing in the community became obsolete. Cultures came to America with their medicine songs, but the longer they stayed, the softer they sang.  I encounter one too many individuals who have been told as a young child that they "can't sing.” Singing has been shown to release mood-elevating endorphins and enhance personal bonds.

In the spirit of building community, I ask for your help in making this album a reality. This project is bigger than me, It is a movement. And your support is essential.

Thank you for taking the time to read this.

 

What We Need 

  • 7 Produced original tracks (one track for each of the 7 major Chakras or energy centers) 

60% of funds raised will go towards recording studio costs, mastering tracks, musician fees, licensing and distribution costs. Album will be produced by award-winning producer, Aaron Bowen 

35% will go towards other expenses including; album art, album release concert, music video production costs (videographer, crew)

5% Extra cushion for unexpected expenses such as additional mastering/recording fees, extra musicians, permits)

What You Get

You get to be part of the process, this movement of radical expression toward self-discovery. You get a grateful heart from me. Music for healing, and a wealth of gratitude bundles for backing this project.

What Happens If We Don't Reach Our Goal

I trust in abundance for this project. But there’s value in planning for all possible outcomes. So, if for some reason I don’t make my goal, the album release party/concert can be scaled down. While I have great visions for it, birthing this album into the world is the priority.

The Impact

Music heals. It really is as simple as that.

For me, music was an outlet I turned to when I started to experience the pressure of adolescence, of not quite fitting in. Music allowed me to express difficult emotions and explore parts of myself that rarely got much stage time. I went on to study music in college, it started to become a dreaded responsibility. I convinced myself I had to fit into a mold and be the perfect vocalist, the perfect performer, and that perspective killed my love for singing. Until I found Kirtan through my yoga teacher training. The ancient practice of chanting was the breath of freshness I needed to rekindle my connection to my voice. My heart opened up. I experienced the transformation of singing for devotion, offering up the duality of sound to something greater than me.

Beyond the research, music connects us to the present moment. It is an effective way to regulate the nervous system and enhance our awareness. It’s a beautiful practice that deserves to be shared. Mantra, chant, toning, humming. We can shift our vibration and recalibrate our thoughts through musical meditation. This is the movement. This is the practice. And this album is rooted in its wisdom.

The voice is a direct expression of the love in our hearts, the power of our worth, and the innate intelligence of our body. The vibrational aspect of the voice accesses stagnated energetic blocks in our body.  

Your support allows me to expand my reach. When people discover freedom in their voice, they embody it. Internal awareness leads to external compassion for the betterment of society as a whole.  

Thank you for be a part of it.

 

Other Ways You Can Help

Make some noise. You can help by sharing this campaign. Use IndieGoGo easy sharing tools. 

Connect with me on social media to follow the progress: @sitarose_yoga

If you live in San Diego, consider volunteering for the big album release party Sunday, May 6, 2018. Or help by posting flyers, invite your friends to attend.

story:
Our recordings are mastered, the cover is designed, help us in the final investment to press the CD...




Feel invited to join us on this sound-journey into the depths of the inner earth, where the nourishing qualities of stillness and the intimacy created by the darkness of the cave are a call to remember and honor our connection with the divine.



The Story of the Cave Recordings

In the early spring of 2015 Max Brumberg and Maxence des Oiseaux started a series of recordings in the famous Cueva de la Pileta in Andalucia. Guided by Tomas Bullon and Karmit Evenzur we entered the cave with a sentiment of deep humility. 



Here we would not be musicians playing music, but individuals played by the music through our instruments of wood, bone and horn…  Music in the moment, outside of time; the notes flowing in ceremony as the space awakens and memories flood our sight in the form of mental images.



The Pileta is a temple dedicated to, and with evident symbolism of, the Feminine:  by way of the geothermic conditions which evoke the maternal womb; by pictorial representations of the vulval form; and most notably by the initial painting which greets us at the entrance of the cave: that of the Venus (our cover), one of the oldest of such paintings known in Europe.





There are strong indications of a connection between these paintings which decorate the cave and the acoustic properties brought to life there in the cave while playing music: Archeological research has found fragments of bones encrusted in stalagmitic accretions demonstrating that humans have long since beat upon these natural lithophones, utilizing this sanctuary for over 30,000 years to the purpose of auditory sensation.

...we were allowed to play them!




On this album we welcome you along on an evocative journey, a peaceful voyage beyond time to bring you to these memories of humanity.




...If you want more, we have already the first Album 'La Cueva de la Pileta'
This was chronologically the second set of recordings we did. Rudi Wienand, Guido Falke and Max Brumberg did several trips to the cave, recording with ancient and mordern music instruments.. You can get this fabulous double album along with the new album.
Here is a preview:



Help us to release the new Album, feel free to spread the news and share our project... 
...Thank you a lot for your support and keep updated for new cave-recordings!!

story:
Short Summary

Hey everyone! We are The Naturals, Marquette University's first and only all-male a cappella group, and we are trying to do something that has never been done before. Marquette has truly become a hotbed for collegiate a cappella, featuring the talents of The Meladies, Gold 'n Blues, and yours truly, but we want to do something to take our school's singing scene to the next level: make the first ever combined a cappella album featuring all three groups.


This album will feature 13 songs total:

  • Four songs by The Naturals - "Electric Love", "Victorious", "Coffee" and "Lady, You Shot Me"
  • Four songs each by The Meladies and Gold 'n Blues
  • A special combined song featuring all the members of ALL 3 GROUPS

The album will be available for download on iTunes and Loudr and for streaming on Spotify.

So why make an album like this? A lot of reasons.

For one, we know that all of our groups are great, but often lack the platform to showcase our sound beyond our individual fan bases. An album breaks down those walls by bringing fans of each group together for a shared musical experience.

In addition, we know Marquette students, faculty and alumni LOVE this school. We feel we can bring the whole MU family together by putting out an amazing album while also saying "thank you" for being a part of this awesome university community.

Last but not least, through working together over the years on other events such as our own concerts, Acatoberfest, and our Christmas Concert, the three groups have realized we work best when we work together. Combining to record one album also allows us to reduce our costs, and being on the same album pushes us to be the best we can be.

What We Need & What You Get

To make this album, each group needs to raise $3000 total for a total cost of just about $9000. Our cost breakdown is roughly as follows:

  • $2300 for recording, mixing and editing by our producers, Matt Caruso and Nick Wright of www.acappellapsych.com
  • $400 for lodging and flights for Matt and Nick when they come to record at Marquette
  • $200 for mastering – the finishing touches an album needs – from www.vocalmastering.com
  • $100 for licensing our music - making it legal - and getting it on iTunes, Loudr and Spotify

To help us get there, we’ve created a variety of “perks” at different levels of funding. These include new Naturals apparel, including stickers, sunglasses, shirts, and the famous Bow Tie itself. We also offer the opportunity to meet us and receive a private performance at a rehearsal and even to help us pick a song for next semester’s setlist!

We are scheduled to record the album from March 4th to March 16th. If we don’t reach our goal, we will spend all the money we do take in to cover these costs, and scrounge up the rest by… well… we’re not sure. Lemonade stands? Garage sales? Shirtless car washes? Yeah, you don’t want it to come to that.

The Impact

Your contribution will directly help make this album become a reality and, in turn, show the world that Marquette a cappella is really, really special. You’ll help us, along with The Meladies and Gold ‘n Blues, increase our presence in Milwaukee and nationally by giving us a tool that we can use to promote ourselves and each other. Every dollar you give will directly go to defraying the cost of recording, producing, and licensing our music. In helping to fund this album, you will help us to make the music we love to make.

You can trust us to deliver because we’ve done this before. Three years ago, you helped us successfully create our first EP and set us on the path to success we’ve had today. Since then, we’ve successfully self-funded two EPs. But this project is more than we can do alone. And with your help, we can make an album that will put Golden Eagles a cappella on the map.

Lastly, you are going to be helping to make a really, really great CD that YOU get to enjoy forever! Each group is bringing their best and is ready to record a phenomenal, one-of-a-kind album, and we know that you will enjoy hearing our voices as recorded by one of the best a cappella music producers in the world today.

Risks & Challenges

We have a short time frame to finish this campaign – it ends on March 21st – and we have a lot of work to do in that time.  However, we’ve done this before. Our leadership team has been a part of 3 EPs, 2 ICCA runs (including last year’s trip to semifinals, putting us in the top 70 groups in the world in 2015) and over 100 concerts and events over the past 4 years.

The logistics of recording may seem challenging, but we’ve got it all figured out. Plane flights have been booked, hotels arranged, and schedules made. We are ready to start recording THIS WEEK.

While it’s not going to be easy to reach our goal, you guys are the best fans in the world. Trust us, and we’ll do everything we can to make this album dream a reality.

Other Ways You Can Help

If you can’t donate directly to our campaign, we totally get it. If you can’t donate, please help us out by sharing our campaign on Facebook (facebook.com/munaturals), Twitter (@munaturals) and Instagram (munaturals). We appreciate your support! You guys rock.

Thanks again for checking out our campaign.

Naturally,

The Naturals

Meladies, Gold 'n Blues, and yours truly, but we want to do something to
take our school's singing scene to the next level: make the first ever
combined a cappella album featuring all three groups.
This
album will feature 13 songs total:

Four songs by
     The Naturals - "Electric Love", "Victorious",
     "Coffee" and "Lady, You Shot Me"
Four songs each
     by The Meladies and Gold 'n Blues
A special
     combined song featuring all the members of ALL 3 GROUPS

The
album will be available for download on iTunes and Loudr and for streaming on
Spotify.
So
why make an album like this? A lot of reasons. 
For
one, we know that all of our groups are great, but often lack the platform
to showcase our sound beyond our individual fan bases. An album breaks down
those walls by bringing fans of each group together for a shared musical
experience. 
In
addition, we know Marquette students, faculty and alumni LOVE
this school. We feel we can bring the whole MU family
together by putting out an amazing album while also saying "thank
you" for being a part of this awesome university community. 
Last
but not least, through working together over the years on other events
such as our own concerts, Acatoberfest, and our
Christmas Concert, the three groups have realized we work best when
we work together. Combining to record one album also allows us to reduce
our costs, and being on the same album pushes us to be
the best we can be.
What We Need & What You Get
To
make this album, each group needs to raise $3000 total for a total cost of just
about $9000. Our cost breakdown is roughly as follows:

$2300 for
     recording, mixing and editing by our producers, Matt Caruso and Nick
     Wright of www.acappellapsych.com
$400 for lodging
     and flights for Matt and Nick when they come to record at Marquette
$200 for
     mastering – the finishing touches an album needs – from www.vocalmastering.com
$100 for
     licensing our music - making it legal - and getting it on iTunes, Loudr
     and Spotify

To
help us get there, we’ve created a variety of “perks” at different levels of
funding. These include new Naturals apparel, including stickers, sunglasses,
shirts, and the famous Bow Tie itself. We also offer the opportunity to meet us
and receive a private performance at a rehearsal and even to help us pick a
song for next semester’s setlist! 
We
are scheduled to record the album from March 4th to March 16th. If we don’t reach our goal, we will spend all the money we
do take in to cover these costs, and scrounge up the rest by… well… we’re not
sure. Lemonade stands? Garage sales? Shirtless car washes? Yeah, you don’t want
it to come to that.
The Impact
Your
contribution will directly help make this album become a reality and, in turn,
show the world that Marquette a cappella is really, really special. You’ll help
us, along with The Meladies and Gold ‘n Blues, increase our presence in
Milwaukee and nationally by giving us a tool that we can use to promote
ourselves and each other. Every dollar you give will directly go to
defraying the cost of recording, producing, and licensing our music. In
helping to fund this album, you will help us to make the music we love to make.
You
can trust us to deliver because we’ve done this before. Three years ago, you
helped us successfully create our first EP and set us on the path to success we’ve
had today. Since then, we’ve successfully self-funded two EPs. But this project
is more than we can do alone. And with your help, we can make an album that
will put Golden Eagles a cappella on the map.
Lastly,
you are going to be helping to make a really, really great CD that YOU get
to enjoy forever! Each group is bringing their best and is ready to record
a phenomenal, one-of-a-kind album, and we know that you will enjoy hearing our
voices as recorded by one of the best a cappella music producers in the world
today.
Risks & Challenges
We
have a short time frame to finish this campaign – it ends on March 21st
– and we have a lot of work to do in that time.  However, we’ve done this
before. Our leadership team has been a part of 3 EPs, 2 ICCA runs (including
last year’s trip to semifinals, putting us in the top 70 groups in the world in
2015) and over 100 concerts and events over the past 4 years. 
The
logistics of recording may seem challenging, but we’ve got it all figured out.
Plane flights have been booked, hotels arranged, and schedules made. We are
ready to start recording THIS WEEK.
While
it’s not going to be easy to reach our goal, you guys are the best fans in
the world. Trust us, and we’ll do everything we can to make this album dream a
reality.
Other Ways You Can Help
If
you can’t donate directly to our campaign, we totally get it. If you can’t
donate, please help us out by sharing our campaign on Facebook
(facebook.com/munaturals), Twitter (@munaturals) and Instagram (munaturals). We
appreciate your support! You guys rock. 
Thanks
again for checking out our campaign.
Naturally,
The
Naturals

story:
Click the arrow in the picture above for a music video preview of our CD

This is now the blog of the Kai Moku Journey -- Late and Breaking will be a reverse chronological set of blog entries.  To read the full story, page down to "The Kai Moku Journey" for a more complete explanation of the background to the blog.
 

Still Raising Funding

Just a short reminder: the Kai Moku Journey is still running a serious deficit.  Even though the formal campaign has ended, you can still contribute to The Kai Moku Journey.

In money raised against hard dollars now spent on tour needs, we are in the red by about $18,500.  We're not home yet.   Your help chipping that away will be greatly appreciated.

You helped us reach the pinnacle, please help us on the way home...


The Pinnacle of the Kai Moku Journey


Late and Breaking


16 July 2015 -- Just got notice when I tried to post last update -- I've run out of space to blog... watch this space for instructions to find the rest of the news


14 July 2015 – We only thought that the retirement home was our last gig.  Formally that was true.  In practice, well… we ended up playing with a band that is apparently quite famous, Chant de Coton Blues Band, at Brasserie le Tagalou.  According to the folks who run le Tagalou, Jam, the lead singer in Chant de Coton Blues Band is among the most famous of French popular singers.

It was a wild night for a bunch of old folks like us.  We went for dinner at seven, and knew the blues band was set to play all evening.  The restaurant was a two minute walk from our flat – its biggest attraction when we chose it. 

The band was setting up as we arrived.  We ended up at the adjacent table as they had their dinner.  The folks at le Tagalou already knew we were from Hawaii and gradually came to understand that we are a band.  When we told them about the Kai Moku Journey, they and the band wanted us to get up and play.

And play we did.  Chant de Coton Blues Band took two breaks to let us hijack their gig – I felt a little guilty, knowing how it is when someone horns in on your gig.  But they said they loved it, were honored to play with us – as we were with them.  Limited to one microphone, one uke, one guitar and one bass, supplemented by their drummer and harmonica player, we played several songs and Sue danced, then DJ danced, and in the second set, DJ got the crowd up and taught them E Huli Makou. 

As with every other place we played, this crowd was enthusiastic in response to our music.  A guy Pat and I had met on the street – we befriended his little dog first, then him – showed up at the restaurant on a date.  He was so excited about the music he brimmed over. 

He said that the spirit and energy of the music touched his soul.  He understood when I said the purpose of our tour was to spread a little aloha around the world.  In his view we were succeeding.

We closed out with Hawaii Aloha and the patrons were truly touched.  One guy, who works for a US company in France, said he hadn’t been to Hawaii but now would be sure to make the trip.

A dozen or more of the patrons, from young to old, came up to us and thanked us for sharing our music and hula.  They had no idea previously what Hawaiian music was, some didn’t know what or where Hawaii was.  Half a dozen said now they must visit the islands.  To those folks, I handed out Molokai post cards and download cards for Na Ohana Hoaloha: LIVE!. 

And I gave a set to the band, too.  Sue stayed on to dance to the music of Chant de Coton Blues Band until well past midnight.  What a night.

Oh, I almost forgot to mention the food.  FANTASTIC!!!  Uncle had Steak Tartar that was spiced to perfection.  The fillet of beef that Pat and I had was nothing short of amazing.  But the salmon that most of the band had – that was beyond amazing – poached and with a Dijon sauce and served cold.  It exploded on the palate.  Every morsel of food was magnificent.

13 July 2015 – Last gig of the tour.  Whew.  We just wrapped up playing at Maison de retraite - ORPEA - Croix-Rousse, located at 19 rue Philibert Roussy in Lyon (04).  We played to an audience of about forty with the residents aged 69 to 102.  Okay so the 102 year old didn’t show for the performance.  I guess they were heading out to the disco and needed to get on their fancy clothes.

Like every other gig on this trip it was a very good experience for the band and brought some happiness to a crowd that lives a pretty tough life.  The facility was clean and nice with a staff that seemed helpful and kind, even warm.  There were visitors, too.  Certainly not everyone in the world gets this quality of care.  Yet, it was not a happy place, but for the moment of distraction.

Sue was a big hit with the old guys.  Two flirted endlessly and one of those two got up twice to dance with her.  He didn’t really want to let go, either.  One older woman had her eye on Uncle Herb.  Got up and walked over and sat down next to him, leaning in to watch the show, of course.  Herb stayed above it all, oblivious.

The staff enjoyed the part where DJ taught hula – and the old guy hanging on to Sue had a blast, too.  The staff did an enthusiastic Hukilau followed by an even more exciting E Huli Makou.  One young woman on staff took to it like a duck to water.  The assembled residents seemed to get a big kick out of watching the staff dancing.

The location was really great, just up the hill from our flat.  Elevation change of maybe 500 or 700 feet.  Auntie and Uncle were joined by Bully for the cab ride, carrying all of our equipment. 

DJ, Sue, Pat, and I hoofed it up the mountain through a beautiful park that was created out of the estate of Joseph Gillette, the namesake of the street where our flat is located – quai Joseph Gillette.  Amazing views from the garden and a huge section of hillside dedicated to native plants. 


The walk down was easier.  Shortly we’ll head over to a restaurant down the block for dinner.  There is a blues band playing shortly after we are planning to arrive.  Should be interesting.

Yesterday, Sunday, was a quiet day for long walks.  A lot of wandering through this amazing city of Lyon.  DJ has become enamored with the frescos, wall art, and even graffiti in general here.  He has been photographing even what appear gang signs.  But the frescos are incredible.


We ended the day with an odd dinner that exceeded ALL expectations.  Almost all services are close don Sunday in France.  Domino’s Pizza was an exception.  Okay, I didn’t like the idea.  I mean, come on, we’re in the culinary capital of the world and we eat at Domino’s?  But what a surprise.  The pizza selection did not resemble US pizza.  I had a salmon and crème fresh pizza that was a gourmet treat.  Each of the four we ordered was more than special.  Domino’s US – take a note, learn from your brothers in Lyon.

Saturday, a day of recovery from our Friday night gig, was the day that Pat and I used to hunt for Moeck recorders – a renaissance instrument that Pat uses in our music but once played in its native sound palate with a band in Springfield, Illinois that referred to themselves as “tootlers” – excellent Renaissance and early Baroque musicians who played for a lot of historic events (which happened all of the time in hometown of Abe Lincoln).

We wandered around and with DJ’s help found a little music shop that sold Yamaha guitars.  The owner there pointed us to a music store about 3 klicks away.  We walked through old town and the high end shopping district of Lyon – there are fashion shop show rooms from Paris designers where they test market their latest designs.  We ended up on Place Bellecour at a wonderful music store, Bellecour Musiques.

Pat found a beautiful pair of Moeck recorders to complete her tonal set --- she found an Ebony alto recorder (lower registers) and a lovely maple soprano.  She started practicing with the band immediately to integrate them in for our Sunday performance.

To close the day Saturday, Pat and DJ and I scoped out restaurants within easy walking distance – Auntie Julia is having a lot of trouble with her knee on this trip – it will be replaced in August.  We found L’assiette du Marche at 21 Grande rue de Vaise, just across the river. 

Amazing does not begin to touch the wonders of the food at this restaurant.  The limited menu gave the band dishes based on rabbit and salmon.  Both were spectacular.  But the thrill of the evening was the executive chef.  No English, yet we were able to communicate.  Hilarious.  We had a taste test comparing his French sea salt to our hand gathered Molokai sea salt.  It was a draw – neither side conceding defeat.  We’ll go back for another meal.

11 July 2015 – The whirlwind has been like a force four tornado.  There has not been a moment to reflect or write since I snuck in the last blog entry after the “big gig” in Geneva.  It’s Saturday morning here and we have two days off before the next gig.  So here’s the story, working backward to Wednesday.


The Aloha Bar

Friday night, Lyon France, old town, the Aloha Bar.  I still have to laugh, the Aloha Bar in Lyon France.  The owner’s never been to Hawaii.  But the theme is well done in the bar.  Think back streets of Waikiki.  Hole in the wall bar, but cool – in a lot of ways it reminded me more of New York, east side of Manhattan, where there are tons of little, themed bars.  Nicola, the owner, sweet, enthusiastic guy.  He has the aloha spirit.

Here’s the bar before opening.

We were at the back of the bar area where we could have some floor space for dancing.  Nice setting. 

The whole gig had been set up by Lisa Arsac, Vice President and Events Coordinator for the American Club – this was a pau hana (after work) informal gathering of the Club members as a reception for the band.  Lisa has been incredible, getting our time in Lyon organized. 

Here’s Lisa with the band – playing my guitar brilliantly (wink, wink – she doesn’t play).  And another shot with her very supportive husband Cyril. 


We started playing about 6:45, warm ups.  Nice small crowd.  I could explain the band and the Kai Moku Journey.  Very attentive.  But the crowd rolled in about seven and we went to town with livelier music and hula. 

The Aloha Bar packed full as the band got rolling.  We were playing acoustically, so pretty soon we were overwhelmed with bar noise.  But the crowd was more than attentive, in their own way.  They requested that we teach them some hula and the party really rocked.

Here’s DJ teaching hula.  The woman in the blue dress and glasses was trained as a belly dancer and picked up hula like she was born to it.  So fun to watch.

Great conversation with American Club folks after we finished playing.  It was clear that a huge portion of the aloha spirit had been served and taken in by this crowd.

Before the gig, our transit from our apartment to the Aloha Bar had been a little rocky.  DJ, Bully, Sue, and I walked.  We stopped at the Music Center to pick up the small bass amplifier I had purchased for our Lyon gigs earlier in the day and Bully carried it the rest of the way to the bar.  Back at the apartment we had bundled the rest of the band and instruments into a Lyon Taxi – thank you Claire Point for helping us negotiate this.  However, the cab dropped off Pat with Auntie and Uncle at the wrong end of the block and pointed them in the wrong direction at the bar end of the ride. 

Ever resourceful, Pat sat Auntie and Uncle down at a café and searched out the gig.  While Auntie was sitting in a chair at the closed bistro, the owner walked up and asked if she needed anything, brought her water, and offered help.  Pat returned with everything scoped out and also had some water while the three waited for the walkers to arrive. 

When Pat tried to leave a couple of Euros in appreciation of the service, the owner said, “Non!”  Jackie wouldn’t take our money.  And having learned what we were there to do, she later showed up and cheered us on at her competitor, the Aloha Bar. 

The story doesn’t end there.  After the gig, the band decided on dinner at Jackie’s restaurant, El Sombrero (9, rue Pizay).  The restaurant has a Mexican chef and Jackie’s husband, the executive chef, is Cordon Bleu trained. The food was beyond amazing.  Here are a bunch of food pictures.

Enchiladas in mole sauce

Chiles rellenos

We retraced our steps back to the apartment and captured great views of Lyon at night.  This is one of the most photogenic cities in the world.

The taxi ride back to the apartment for Pat, Uncle, and Auntie was a little more eventful.  One way streets required a different route.  The shortcut of the tunnel was “ferme” – closed – so the taxi headed over the mountain.  What mountain, one might ask.  One Pat did.  And they flew down a winding, narrow road, flashing brights and waiting for oncoming traffic because it was essentially one lane.  But, according to Pat, the views were more than spectacular as they entered the Saône Valley from the mountain top.

We debriefed in the comfort of our very posh flat on the Saône.

Kanikapila at Claire’s House

Lyon is the home of Claire Point, her husband Sebastian, and her three sons.  Claire is an important person in my life and has been for more than a decade.  She arrived in my life as an intern at Chelsea Group.  During her time in that role she lived in our home in Itasca, Illinois.  Many important life stories for Pat and me revolve around Claire.

Claire was so kind as to invite the entire band into her home the evening we arrived in Lyon.  She drove to our flat from her home 15 klicks upstream on the Saône in a van borrowed from a neighbor.  We piled into the van and felt like we’d gone home.  Here’s Claire with the van and you’ll quickly see why we were so comfortable.

A ’68 Ford Econoline, with wood panel interior and signage offering its origin in Haliewa, Hawaii – a town on the North Shore of Oahu where big wave surfing is life.  Claire, you outdid yourself.  But the best was yet to come.

The drive to Claire’s home took us up the Saône Valley through beautiful scenery just as the sun was beginning to set.  Here’s a picture of the dashboard hula dancer with the Saône, a barge, and the Saône Valley in the background. 

We arrived at Claire’s home in Neuville sur Saône as the bells chimed on the half hour.  She piloted the enormous van into the tiny back street and parked near her front door. 

The home was built in the late 1800s.  It is built of Saône river rock, just like the garden wall below, but covered with hard plaster.  Sebastian, Claire’s husband, has beautifully renovated the kitchen.  Through the kitchen we entered the amazing courtyard. 

We played for our dinner.  Claire and Sebastian, friends Oliver and Angela, and Claire’s cat paid rapt attention as we played song after song.  Sue danced.  Angela, trained in classical ballet, tried to learn hula as she went, but finally just let the music move her.

It was midnight before we landed back at the flat.  Pat had stayed home because of her cold and deeply saddened to hear what she had missed.

Travel from Geneva to Lyon

Adventure.  Daring.  Seductive Hawaiian music.  Confusion.  Error.  Recovery.  We had it all.

We had arranged to take the train from Geneva to Lyon.  JP, our harmonica player left us in Geneva to return to Bristol and personal obligations.  I dropped him at the airport after packing the equipment at the US Mission and having a great chat with Ambassador Hamamoto. 

Pat and I dropped off the rest of the band at the train station in downtown Geneva.  We had difficulty exiting the parking garage because of misdirection about parking fees.  Next, Pat and I go lost trying to exit downtown Geneva for the airport.  We took one wrong turn and entered one way hell.  We were separated when Pat got caught in a turn lane and I went on to the next intersection. We were both panicked and running out of time, driving separate cars and with no communications since her phone was dead.

I wiggled through a new route that took me in an odd way into the airport.  Pat was trapped in the lake shore drive but then found her way to the route we knew from our commute to our house in Segny.  With zero communication some sort of odd magic happened and we ended up together as we entered the Budget return gate.  Both of us were greatly relieved.

But then we were on to the sprint to find the train from the airport to the railway depot in downtown Geneva.  Signage was unhelpful.  Finally a kind Police Officer pointed us to the train offices where a very, very sweet woman guided us to our proper course.  We grabbed the next train and made it just in time to join the rest of the band in boarding the train to the French frontier where we were supposed to change trains to catch “Lyon Part Dieu”. 

We missed the stop at Bellegarde.  Clueless.  DJ and I ran to find the conductor.  No English.  Again, magic happened and two young women, Sisters Mattinson and Baggs, doing their missionary work in France (I am not making this up there’s a picture of them below) appeared and translated.  Yes, the conductor explained, we could catch a different Lyon Part Dieu train from the next station and arrive only a few minutes later.

That left us on the platform at Aix-les-Bains for nearly an hour.  Pat broke out her ukulele, then Julia.  Pretty soon the platform was alive with music, hula, and aloha.  Pat taught this little girl how to strum the ukulele.

Spread the aloha.

Island Nations

Soundcheck seemed to draw the crowd down from security into the garden.  The Ambassador spoke briefly and then we exploded into Tewe Tewe.  The party was on.  Over 200 representatives of the smaller island nations gathered to coalesce around the band and the spirit of aloha.  The Swiss halau was in top form.  The audience, this time seated in auditorium format on the well shaded lawn, responded to the energy of the set.

It was grand, dream-like: Wednesday afternoon, five to seven, back at the garden on the campus of the US Mission in Geneva, the security and staff treat us as part of the team.  It is a nice feeling.  We can hardly take a step without someone thanking us for the beautiful music and bringing the spirit of aloha to Geneva station.

The interaction with the audience was different in nature.  At the end of the performance we chatted with folks comfortably.  They were full of questions and we did our best to answer.  It was clear that the music and hula touched them with the spirit of aloha.

The band had spent the prior 24 hours recovering from the Tuesday Independence Day celebration.  The high temperatures on Tuesday had cooked the band – it turned out to be the hottest day on record in Geneva, ever, any day, since records have been kept – which is a long time.  Fortunately the pool at the house had been cleaned and we were able to cool off a bit, even though the water was near 90 degrees F.  It helped.

We had grand plans for our “time off” on Wednesday.  Mostly we slept or walked around in a daze.  My fingers hurt from the long guitar session the day before.  Bully’s hand was cramping.  Pat’s voice was rough.  Auntie was just exhausted.  DJ, somewhat bouncy, kept our spirits agitated.  We prepared for the long day ahead.

The day did not end with the performance for the Island Nations.  Ambassador Hamamoto invited us to her residence on Lake Geneva for a private dinner – just Pam and the band.  And in that context, it was Pam, not “The Ambassador”.  We kicked off our shoes, talked in Pidgeon, and swapped stories of Hawaii. 

Most important, we got to play with Sandy, Pam’s beautiful old dog. 

Pat and I had met Sandy when we had visited Pam at her California home a few years ago.  Sweet, sweet dog.  She so reminds me of Rufus.  I rolled on the floor playing with her.  Despite the elegant surroundings, it was a perfectly comfortable thing to do.  But then, that’s the tone Pam set. 

The meal was unforgettable.  Pam’s chef at the residence, Hussein, is originally from Senegal.  Fabulous chef with a touch for flavors and presentation unparalleled in my experience.  Each course was a jewel in its own right and the combination sparkled like a tiara.

We talked long into the night.  It was hard to say goodbye.  Pam is a gracious host and a good friend.  Like the band, she lives aloha.  Our country is fortunate to have someone with such talent and substance in our service.


8 July 2015 – We’re all recovering from a natural high.  Buoyed by a huge dose of the spirit of aloha, we all stayed up into the night talking through the excitement and joy of a hugely successful performance for the US Mission to the United Nations yesterday. 

Here's the video

From the Ambassador – Pam Hamamoto: feedback from the audience was that the gathered 1,200 or so diplomats from over 170 countries had an overwhelming positive response to the combination of her speech on spreading the spirit of aloha and the music and dance we brought to the event. 

A celebration of the US Independence Day yielded not the usual jingoism but instead a spirit of global cooperation to solve the pressing problems we all know from the world news.

This is what Pam had asked us to do and we did it. 

Plus it was a lot of fun. 

We performed in three sets.  The first set was the welcome.  We played while the participants in the event passed through the beautifully done security process and through the reception line.  Four Ambassadors – Pam is head of station – greeted the guests.  Our music and the dancing of the Swiss halau brought them into the heart of the event.

Once the guests were all in and security closed the gates, the ceremony celebrating the birth of the United States was underway.  A Marine Honor Guard presented the colors.  A quartet of State Department officials from the Geneva Mission provided a brilliant rendition of the Star Spangled Banner.  It brought tears to our eyes – a magical interpretation hauntingly performed in soaring harmonies.

Pam’s speech equally reached the highest levels of diplomatic presentation.  From the band’s perspective we were most honored by this: Last year Pam made a commitment to bring the spirit of aloha to her work with the UN in Geneva; this year she brought us, as the flesh and blood embodiment of that spirit, as an emblem of how that spirit is being realized.  Na Ohana Hoaloha was presented to the world as the living embodiment of the Spirit of Aloha.

This is a duty we do not take lightly.  And in the second set we demonstrated how, through international cooperation with a Swiss hula halau, the musical and dance heritage of Hawaii could be shared with everyone.  Plus we were ON! 

The weather did not make this easy.  The temperature crossed 40 degrees C (100+ degrees F) and there was no wind.  Bully became dizzy.  Auntie lost her place.  All of us dripped with sweat.  But we persisted.  And we performed at the top of our game. 

The coordination with the Swiss began in the fall of 2014.  Their halau sent representatives to Molokai in early February to coordinate.  But it was not until July 6th that we were able to practice together.  No one in the audience would have guessed that.  The flow of the program and quality of song and dance presented to the audience was nearly flawless.

We opened with a song from our new album, Tewe Tewe.  Our arrangement combines chant, powerful ipu rhythms, and intense starts of the vocal segments.  There were cheers among the audience.  The Swiss followed that with some beautiful kahiko (ancient) hula danced to their own chants and ipu. 

We restarted with a song that will be on our next album, Mokio Sunrise.  That was followed by Green Rose Hula.  Our arrangement of the song alternates full band and acapella versions of the verse.  The Swiss danced and played ipu as they did – the combination through the acapella verses created an impression of a cross between kahiko and auana that was very compelling.  Again, huge audience response.

We finally took a break after the second set and grabbed a light lunch from what was left of the buffet.  Standing in the shade of the trees was a real relief after the stage heat.

The third set was more of a real party for us.  We kicked it off with teaching a bunch of very enthusiastic folks how to do the Hukilau, an easy hula taught by DJ with support from Sue and the Swiss halau.  That was followed by Hawaiian Hoki-poki.  We had three ambassadors up dancing – led by Pam.  Laughter filled the grounds.  A childlike joy filled the hearts of all.

Days like this are not just rare.  We have reached the pinnacle of the Kai Moku Journey.  Now we will wind our way down the mountain as we spread a little more aloha in Geneva and then on to Lyon to share some more.

Watch this space…

6 July 2015 – We made it to Geneva.  Thanks to help from JP and his son Michael, the departure went smoothly from Bristol, England.  Yesterday, which was Sunday the 5th, we had an early, early start.  We left JP’s house a little before 4am. 

The dawn trip through the English countryside was beautiful.  The farms surrounding Bristol were just waking up.  The light gave a gold tint to the crops and windrows shedding precious insight into the spirit of the land.  Farm homes and out buildings, many from three, four, and five centuries past, took on a warmth that bespoke the energy of their people.

JP herded our band of cats through the early morning crowds.  His experience as a world traveler shone through – kindness to the harried EasyJet staff was reciprocated with easy passage for us.  Pat’s arrangement were again flawless.

Here’s a picture of our row of musicians on the EasyJet Plane

Martin, our friend from the US Mission in Geneva, met us at the baggage claim once we landed.  This was a purely volunteer effort on Martin’s part – he took time away from his visiting family to greet us.  He took up JP’s role and used his diplomatic credentials to smooth our way.  Martin, if you recall, is a top notch bass player.  He and Bully bonded over the ukulele bass and their preferences in music.  THANK YOU, Martin!

Soon enough we were rolling through the French countryside on our way to the home we rented in Segny (“Sig-Knee”).  Sundays are quiet days in rural France.  The only place open for lunch was an American bistro known throughout the world as McDonalds.  We munched on French Micky-D food while we waited for the property manager to open the house.  The food was good.  I had a goat cheese wrap that was beyond delicious and the best thing I remember eating at a McDonalds.

The house turned out to be just as amazing as we imagined.  We quickly divvied up sleeping space and everyone was comfortable.  The heat is the only problem.  They had warned us as we landed that the temperature would be 38.  That’s in degrees C.  Read 99 in degrees F.  Killa.

The view from the house

The temperature came down in the evening, heading for the mid 20s – 70-ish.  We went out to dinner at one of the few places open and had a wonderful experience.  With JP speaking French, seemingly fluently, we had an easy time of picking great menu items and getting great services from a very friendly staff. 

Here’s a picture of the 282 Bistro

Monday is the start of practice for the BIG DAY.  Weather report says sunny, but HOT, HOT, HOT.  But it was about 72 at breakfast and we had a beautiful view of the mountains, too.


The outdoor event on Tuesday will likely be in 38+ (100+) degree weather.  Good thing we’re tough from our hot stage at Paddlers’ Inn on Molokai, but it sure would have been nice for us to play in typical Geneva summer weather of 75 and sunny.  Never let a little thing like that get in the way of a good time, though.

Watch this space!


4 July 2015 – Happy Birthday America!  And Happy Birthday Hannah Parsons – JP’s beautiful granddaughter.  We’re still staying with Michael and his family in Bristol England.  Here's the house with Pat going in the walk.


We have our second gig tonight at the Victoria Pub.

Here’s a picture of the Victoria Pub, Bully keeping it standing

The owner saw us play at the Duck and almost instantly set up for us to play the Saturday night crowd at her place.  Here’s the poster she developed (and signed, “with much love, Rhone”) for us.

Rhona fed us extremely well.  The food at the Victoria is excellent.  We had several different entrees among us and everyone loved their choices.  Here’s a shot of pub food.

Then it was time to play and play we did.  Here’s a shot of DJ, Julia, and Pat getting settled into the nicely decorated impromptu stage Rhona put together for us.

What a night!  Folks who had seen us at the Duck started showing up.  The place packed up.  We already have Na Ohana Hoaloha groupies in Bristol England!  One couple there was so enthused they invited us to come back next year to play for their wedding.  Another couple, with the woman due with a baby girl at any moment, want to visit and consider moving to Hawaii after the experience.  She even danced the hula when DJ taught the Hukilau – but threatened to have her baby right then and there!


4 July 2015 – A day of touring with our intrepid guide, Michael Parsons.  Not only is he an incredible host for our visit to Bristol, he is a brilliant tour guide.  Michael is a highly skilled and qualified buildings expert.  He gave us an amazing perspective on the history of Bristol through its architecture. 

Here is Michael with the Transit Van that JP rented to take us around England

The bridge over the Avon Gorge is truly a wonder.  Designed in 1831, it continues today to link the commercial and residential centers of Bristol.  It is an elegant beauty. 

Here is a picture of the bridge

Michael snapped a shot of us as we posed at the beginning of the bridge walkway.  DJ is on the left, Uncle Herb next, then Pat, Sue, and finally George on the right.

At the bridge crossing there is a rock formation that has been worn by use into a very clever slide.  Our host demonstrated his boyish character by sliding down it.  But it was Sue that had requested that we visit it.  We were all stunned as Sue showed the tomboy in her Angel-hula dancer presence and bounced down the rough, rocky slide, worn to shiny by all the little boys’ butts that preceded her.

Here’s a picture of Sue sliding down the cliffs of the Avon Gorge.


We’re off shortly to play our second gig.  I’m excited to be getting ready to head to Geneva, too.

Watch this space!


3 July 2015 – The Black Swan Pub (known to the regulars as the Dirty Duck, or just the Duck) will never be the same after the hula lesson and the closing circle.  The Aloha Spirit was palpable by the end of our performance.  Here’s video of Sue inspiring the pub crowd to take up hula.

Joining us for the evening was JP’s grandson Joshua.  He got the crowd into sing-along mode with a hit from the 1960s by the Monkeys called “I’m a Believer”.  Here’s a clip of Joshua leading the crowd in that song.

The session ended with a request from the audience for two things – a simple hula that DJ could teach them and for us to sing the song Hukilau.  We combined the two requests and DJ taught about ten or so folks how to dance the Hukilau while the band played it once slowly for teaching purposes and then once up to full speed.  What a blast.  They were quick learners!

The evening ended with a request from the owner of a nearby pub to play Saturday night at her place. 

More to come…. Watch this space!


2 July 2015 – We’re in England now, getting ready for our first pub gig.  We arrived yesterday, about 25 hours from the time we got going on Oahu and more than 40 hours from the time we left Molokai.  The whole band was together for the flight across the country and the Atlantic. 

Here’s our band upon arrival at Heathrow in London


Our Harmonica Player, JP (John Parsons), and his grandson Joshua (at right in photo above) picked us up in a 14-passenger Transit Van and ferried us to Bristol.  There we were warmly welcomed by Joshua’s parents, Michael and Natasha, and his sister Hannah.  JP, ever the proud grandpa, shepherded us around the town.

Here’s the view from the “tower room” at Michael’s home, where Pat and I found a comfortable bed waiting for our worn and jetlagged selves.

We spent an hour at the pub where we’ll play tonight.  JP’s friend Chris and a group of pub goers welcomed us.  The sign out front let everyone know that tonight (Thursday, July 2) will be Hawaiian night with live music all the way from the Islands.

Joshua, JP, and Michael fed us a marvelous pasta dinner and we all retired to sleep off the travel.

Watch this space!

30 June 2015 – Aloha Molokai and Hawaii Nei! 


We had a great send off by Shari and the staff of the Admirals Club in Honolulu.  They are old friends.  Gotta mention Armie Pilicara-Woods, who saved our butts on check-in details, but wasn’t there to see us off.  And to Shari for working her magic to make seating better than expected.

We’re across the Pacific now, at the LAX Admirals Club.  We took over a corner of the Club and a friendly French speaking person took a picture of the whole band.


We’re all doing well and in good spirits.

Watch this space


30 June 2015 – We’ll be boarding the plane at Honolulu International to Heathrow in just a few hours now.  It was an eventful and important day today.  Pat, Bully, and I left topside Molokai at about 1:30 pm and began our Kai Moku Journey with a short plane ride to Kalaupapa, the former Leper Colony and site of the miracles of Saint Damien and Saint Marianne. 

Kalaupapa comes into view

The final approach to the landing strip at Kalaupapa

Here’s a picture of the three of us at the Kalaupapa airport terminal

The plane from Molokai is a luxurious ride.  We flew Mokulele, one of my favorite airlines of all time.  Captain Christian and co-pilot Bonny brought us in on the tiny runway at the edge of the ocean on this most isolated of peninsulas in the world. 

Captain Christian and co-pilot Bonny with Pat and Bully in front of their plane

The terminal at Kalaupapa

We’re still wrapping up details as I write this.  Bully is resting on the futon in my Kailua apartment on Oahu – yes, we made it on the first leg of our journey. 


29 June 2015 -- It is official, after our Geneva gigs, we are playing at the Aloha Bar in Lyon, France.  Come join us at 7 pm on 10 July 2015!  It will also be a reception for the American Club of Lyon.  The public is welcome.

Here is the invitation:

Special Hawaiian

Happy Hour

Aloha!  Come out and join us for a special Hawaiian Happy Hour

Let’s get together for some exotic drinks and island atmosphere while enjoying an authentic

Hawaiian music and dance performance by Na Ohana Noaloha (A Family of Friends)

The Aloha bar is also offering ACL members a

Happy Hour drink special of Hawaiian beer 5€ ( 7€ normally),

and all cocktails 8€ (9€ or 10€ normally)

When: Friday, July 10th at 6:30 pm (band starting at 7pm)

Where: Aloha Bar, 4 rue Pizay, Lyon 69001


Watch this space...


28 June 2015 – Frantic, frantic, frantic.  A million more things to do before we leave and that is TOMORROW!  Really, we’re in great shape thanks to Pat’s incredible organizational skills.  It is more like a million details to be cleared up, not a million important things to do. 

Pat works here with Julia on tailoring her costume --

The band met again yesterday and went over all of the arrangements.

Everyone flies over to Honolulu tomorrow, Monday, June 29th, and gets set for the early departure on Tuesday.  We’re all staying with family or friends – THANK YOU for your continuing support and willingness to get up before dawn to see us off.  We rendezvous at HNL between 4:45 and 5:00 am on Tuesday morning.  And then… we’re leaving on a jet plane…

Today is our last regular weekly performance at Paddlers’ Inn before we head into the wild blue yonder.  We’ve picked out songs from the tour book and we’ll use the performance as a practice of sorts.  Should be a good send-off with all of our regulars there to cheer us on.

Bully has been hanging with his other musician friends and says that they are happy to see us be, as they call it, “ambassadors for Molokai”.  Thanks, guys, and proud to do it.

We’re still in pre-release for our CD.  We’ve had some good feedback and I got the CD into the hands of Derrek Malama, a great DJ who does his “Kanekapila Sunday” every week on Hawaii Public Radio – great show.  He’s also the host of Morning Edition on HPR, so you may have heard his voice if you are an NPR freak like me.  I’m hoping Derrek likes a few cuts and gives us some air time.  Thanks to Deane Neubauer – regular supporter and fan of ours – for making the introduction to Derrek.

For you on-line music buyers, we’re up on iTunes now, as well as CDbaby.  Look for Na Ohana Hoaloha: LIVE!

Well, time to pull everything together for this performance.  Aloha no.

Watch this space…


22 June 2015 – Things spinning faster and faster, so many moving parts, but some things are locking down, too. 

Number one best news: the case full of instruments we shipped to the US Mission in Geneva is there, has passed through customs, and is now in the trusted hands of Martin The Bass Player (see 17 June entry). 

Number two best news: Na Ohana Hoalaoha: LIVE! is in hand, including the CD in beautiful DigiPaks, the CDbaby Digital Download Cards for the diplomats, and our lovely posters. 

Proof that it is real:

We plopped a CD in a few different players and the sound is GREAT.  Thank you Bully, thank you DiscMakers.  And for you on-line music buyers, you’ll be finding the album on Amazon, iTunes, and elsewhere over the next few days. 

If you want it RIGHT NOW, you can just click over to http://cdbaby.com/cd/naohanahoaloha

We’ve developed our pre-release approach and have a draft of our launch events in Europe and in the US.  For those of you who have done this before, we are open to tips on effective kick-off efforts.

The European launch will, of course, be the July event in Geneva, were “world-wide distribution” will earn its name.  We will hand CDbaby Digital Download Card of Na Ohana Hoaloha: LIVE! to representatives of over 170 nations while they listen to us play. 

The US Launch will take place upon our triumphant return to Paddlers Inn on Molokai.  We’re scheduling it for Sunday, July 19th.  It’s going to be a blast.  We’ll show videos and photos from our European Tour.  The State Department will be filming our programs in Geneva and they have offered to share.  We’ll play a little of the music, talk story, and soak in the good vibes.

Watch this space!


17 June 2015 – Things are spinning up pretty fast now.  Our new album, Na Ohana Hoaloha: LIVE! Launched in digital download form on Sunday and is available at http://cdbaby.com/cd/naohanahoaloha and looks great and sounds great.  You can listen to samplings of the music at that site and buy if you like – one song at a time or the whole shootin’ match. 

Our instruments shipped from Molokai, headed for Geneva Switzerland on Tuesday (June 16).  Pat and George stayed up ‘til past midnight packing the case and doing the shipping paperwork.  Both talked to Martin in shipping and receiving at the US Mission to the United Nations in Geneva to make the arrangements for their receipt. 

So cool, turns out Martin has played bass professionally, so he was totally understanding of our trepidation at shipping our favorite instruments!  They are slated to arrive in Geneva on June 23rd.  Martin will check them out and make sure everything is playable.  We’re much more comfortable having talked to Martin.

Here are two pictures of Martin -- the manager of the shipping and receiving activities at the US Mission in Geneva --  as I said, cool...

          

 

We heard back from our contact at the American Club of Lyon, France, too.  Lisa, a Vice President of the Club and an events coordinator, is setting up a reception at the Aloha Bar in Lyon – can you believe it a Hawaiian themed bar in Lyon France!

Here’s the funny part -- we had checked their Facebook page and found the Aloha Bar was forced to close on June 9th for structural repairs to their building.  We were bummed.  On Sunday the band talked about offering to do some sort of fundraiser to help them back on their feet.  But lo, and much to our surprise, they are already back in business.

So it looks like really cool gigs in three countries – England (Bristol), Switzerland (Geneva), and France (Lyon).  Still looking for more gigs – retirement center or something – in Lyon, too.

Watch this space...


14 June 2015 -- The date of the departure from Molokai grows closer.  And closer.   We've locked in virtually all of our travel arrangements now.  Tomorrow we ship our instruments to the US Mission to the UN in Geneva.  The band spent all day yesterday going over progress and plans.

You'll see that ukuleles are in hand.  They are like teddy bears or blankies -- if you remember Linus from the Peanuts gang. 

Virtually every detail of our travel plans is locked down now – thank you Pat.  You can see the pages with golden color on them – these are our play lists for the Geneva performances.  All of these are locked in now too.

We’ve made a lot of accommodations to reduce the cost of the trip. One really good example is the U-bass (an ukulele set up like a bass guitar). We found it costs about ¼ as much to buy Bully a U-bass than to ship his beautiful Modulus electric bass to and from Geneva.  Bully is extremely happy with the new little bass, which sounds just like a stand-up bass when amplified.  He’s even happier now that we have installed Aquila “red” strings, like we use on all of our regular ukuleles.  They have a smooth and gentle touch. 

Our CD is in the final stages of production at Discmakers with a ship date of June 16th – this coming Tuesday.  The electronic version of the CD is already up on CDbaby and will launch on Amazon and iTunes in a week or so.  Check it out -- http://cdbaby.com/cd/naohanahoaloha and read the album notes on that site. 

Watch this space…


The Kai Moku Journey

 

Kai Moku means the changing tide in Hawaiian.  With your help, our band, Na Ohana Hoaloha (translation: Family of Friends) will bring a tide of aloha to the international diplomatic community at the United Nations in Geneva, Switzerland this July.  We are still about $20,000 short of the funds we need to make this a comfortable trip for the band.  Here's how your contribution will help:

  • Complete the production of our "Na Ohana Hoaloha: LIVE!" album to provide a lasting statement of aloha in our songs
  • Support the logistical needs of the band, which have proven much more costly than estimated
  • Demonstrate your aloha to the world (and get a PERK if you like)

Please make your contribution on this page -- and you can select a PERK at the same time. 

**********

Read on for a fuller explanation of the journey.  For a deeper dive, see and listen to our first indiegogo campaign at --

http://igg.me/at/NOHMKK/x/10072843

How We Got Here

US Ambassador Pamela Hamamoto in her speech to the US Independence Day celebration last year remarked: "I thought long and hard about how best to bring the aloha spirit all the way from Hawaii, 7,700 miles — or I should say, 12,000 kilometers! – and spread it around Geneva, the UN, and all the international organizations. "  She chose to bring our little band from the island of Molokai, Hawaii, to this year's celebration to do just that.

This is our second campaign to raise funding for Kai Moku.  Our first effort, which closed on May 2nd,  achieved 26% (about $10,000) of our goal of $35,000.  

Over 1,250 people looked at, listened to, and read about Kai Moku  at http://igg.me/at/NOHMKK/x/10072843   Have a look and find out why they contributed.

We're opening this site to continue our fund raising efforts.  We hope to more than achieve our modest goal, which will allow us to keep the site open into the future.  We plan to share photos, descriptions, and video from the Kai Moku journey as it happens.  But we still need your help.


Watch the Journey Unfold

Recording for the Tour

The band made a commitment to provide a recording of our songs to commemorate the performance for the UN crowd.    Creating and producing that album has been quite an adventure.  For one thing, the CD project has had a name change.  Now it is "Na Ohana Hoaloha: LIVE!"  We've completed the mixing and mastering, the graphics, and the supporting information and we've reviewed the proofs from our production house: we're on target to deliver the CD in Geneva!

Na Ohana Hoaloha shifted its CD plan to a set of covers of traditional and contemporary Hawaiian music.  The new plan is based on our live program performances recorded every Sunday at Paddler’s Inn and Restaurant on the island of Molokai.

The Kai Moku Album Notes

Na Ohana Hoaloha: LIVE! … Album Notes on CD Baby:

Take a little trip to the island of Moloka'i. Na Ohana Hoaloha has drawn well over 10,000 audience members to its Sunday afternoon performances of Hawaiian music and hula over the past ten years. Here is your chance to hear some of our great performance time captured live and in full audio color.

The album opens with a rousing version of "Tewe Tewe", a classic Hawaiian song performed here in part chant, part chorus. Heavy on the rhythm of the islands, you can understand, even without knowing the Hawaiian language, that this song about catching fish isn't just about fishing. Squirming, squirming. Is that about fish or...

An old song reborn, the next track is "Green Rose Hula". Only Na Ohana Hoaloha can pull off this combination of rapid guitar work balanced against a cappella runs of each verse. Harmonies abound.

"Hi'ilawe", a classic of the Hawaiian scene, is done here in a version for which beautiful choreography has been developed by band member and kumu hula (teacher or master of hula) DJ Pelekai. A warm version or the song, DJ's beautiful voice lets it paint a picture of the waterfalls at Hi'ilawe while portraying the emotions of two lovers as they learn of the gossip flying around about them.

"Holoholo" in Hawaiian is similar to the idea of walkabout in Australia. "Holoholo Fun" is an original song by band member George Benda and was inspired by his dog Rufus, a Golden Retriever that was the neighborhood dog ambassador. Rufus had a "happy dance" as he walked that is captured in the energy and bounce of this song.

"Hula 'O Ma
story_txt:
Click the arrow in the picture above for a music video preview of our CD This is now the blog of the Kai Moku Journey -- Late and Breaking will be a reverse chronological set of blog entries.  To read the full story, page down to "The Kai Moku Journey" for a more complete explanation of the background to the blog.
 Still Raising Funding
Just a short reminder: the Kai Moku Journey is still running a serious deficit.  Even though the formal campaign has ended, you can still contribute to The Kai Moku Journey.In money raised against hard dollars now spent on tour needs, we are in the red by about $18,500.  We're not home yet.   Your help chipping that away will be greatly appreciated.You helped us reach the pinnacle, please help us on the way home...The Pinnacle of the Kai Moku Journey

Late and Breaking


































16 July 2015 -- Just got notice when I tried to post last update -- I've run out of space to blog... watch this space for instructions to find the rest of the news14 July 2015 – We only thought that the retirement home was
our last gig.  Formally that was
true.  In practice, well… we ended up
playing with a band that is apparently quite famous, Chant de Coton Blues Band, at Brasserie
le Tagalou.  According to the folks
who run le Tagalou, Jam, the lead singer in Chant de Coton Blues Band is among
the most famous of French popular singers.
It was a wild night for a bunch of old folks like us.  We went for dinner at seven, and knew the
blues band was set to play all evening. 
The restaurant was a two minute walk from our flat – its biggest
attraction when we chose it.  The band
was setting up as we arrived.  We ended
up at the adjacent table as they had their dinner.  The folks at le Tagalou already knew we were
from Hawaii and gradually came to understand that we are a band.  When we told them about the Kai Moku Journey, they and the band
wanted us to get up and play.

And play we did. 
Chant de Coton Blues Band took two breaks to let us hijack their gig – I
felt a little guilty, knowing how it is when someone horns in on your gig.  But they said they loved it, were honored to
play with us – as we were with them. 
Limited to one microphone, one uke, one guitar and one bass,
supplemented by their drummer and harmonica player, we played several songs and
Sue danced, then DJ danced, and in the second set, DJ got the crowd up and
taught them E Huli Makou.  

As with every other place we played, this crowd was
enthusiastic in response to our music.  A
guy Pat and I had met on the street – we befriended his little dog first, then
him – showed up at the restaurant on a date. 
He was so excited about the music he brimmed over.  He said that the spirit and energy of the
music touched his soul.  He understood
when I said the purpose of our tour was to spread a little aloha around the
world.  In his view we were succeeding.

We closed out with Hawaii
Aloha and the patrons were truly touched. 
One guy, who works for a US company in France, said he hadn’t been to
Hawaii but now would be sure to make the trip.

A dozen or more of the patrons, from young to old, came up
to us and thanked us for sharing our music and hula.  They had no idea previously what Hawaiian
music was, some didn’t know what or where Hawaii was.  Half a dozen said now they must visit the
islands.  To those folks, I handed out
Molokai post cards and download cards for Na Ohana Hoaloha: LIVE!.  And I gave a set to the band, too.  Sue stayed on to dance to the music of Chant
de Coton Blues Band until well past midnight. 
What a night.

Oh, I almost forgot to mention the food.  FANTASTIC!!! 
Uncle had Steak Tartar that was spiced to perfection.  The fillet of beef that Pat and I had was
nothing short of amazing.  But the salmon
that most of the band had – that was beyond amazing – poached and with a Dijon
sauce and served cold.  It exploded on
the palate.  Every morsel of food was
magnificent.

13 July 2015 – Last gig of the tour.  Whew. 
We just wrapped up playing at Maison
de retraite - ORPEA - Croix-Rousse, located at 19 rue Philibert Roussy in
Lyon (04).  We played to an audience of
about forty with the residents aged 69 to 102. 
Okay so the 102 year old didn’t show for the performance.  I guess they were heading out to the disco
and needed to get on their fancy clothes. 

Like every other gig on this trip it was a very good
experience for the band and brought some happiness to a crowd that lives a
pretty tough life.  The facility was
clean and nice with a staff that seemed helpful and kind, even warm.  There were visitors, too.  Certainly not everyone in the world gets this
quality of care.  Yet, it was not a happy
place, but for the moment of distraction.

Sue was a big hit with the old guys.  Two flirted endlessly and one of those two
got up twice to dance with her.  He
didn’t really want to let go, either. 
One older woman had her eye on Uncle Herb.  Got up and walked over and sat down next to
him, leaning in to watch the show, of course. 
Herb stayed above it all, oblivious.
The staff enjoyed the part where DJ taught hula – and the
old guy hanging on to Sue had a blast, too. 
The staff did an enthusiastic Hukilau
followed by an even more exciting E Huli
Makou.  One young woman on staff took
to it like a duck to water.  The
assembled residents seemed to get a big kick out of watching the staff dancing.

The location was really great, just up the hill from our
flat.  Elevation change of maybe 500 or
700 feet.  Auntie and Uncle were joined
by Bully for the cab ride, carrying all of our equipment.  DJ, Sue, Pat, and I hoofed it up the mountain
through a beautiful park that was created out of the estate of Joseph Gillette,
the namesake of the street where our flat is located – quai Joseph Gillette.  Amazing views from the garden and a huge section
of hillside dedicated to native plants.  The walk down was easier. 
Shortly we’ll head over to a restaurant down the block for dinner.  There is a blues band playing shortly after
we are planning to arrive.  Should be
interesting.

Yesterday, Sunday, was a quiet day for long walks.  A lot of wandering through this amazing city
of Lyon.  DJ has become enamored with the
frescos, wall art, and even graffiti in general here.  He has been photographing even what appear
gang signs.  But the frescos are incredible.

We ended the day with an odd dinner that
exceeded ALL expectations.  Almost all
services are close don Sunday in France. 
Domino’s Pizza was an
exception.  Okay, I didn’t like the
idea.  I mean, come on, we’re in the
