culinary capital of the world and we eat at Domino’s?  But what a surprise.  The pizza selection did not resemble US
pizza.  I had a salmon and crème fresh
pizza that was a gourmet treat.  Each of
the four we ordered was more than special. 
Domino’s US – take a note, learn from your brothers in Lyon.

Saturday, a day of recovery from our Friday night gig, was
the day that Pat and I used to hunt for Moeck recorders – a renaissance
instrument that Pat uses in our music but once played in its native sound
palate with a band in Springfield, Illinois that referred to themselves as “tootlers”
– excellent Renaissance and early Baroque musicians who played for a lot of
historic events (which happened all of the time in hometown of Abe Lincoln).

We wandered around and with DJ’s help found a little music
shop that sold Yamaha guitars.  The owner
there pointed us to a music store about 3 klicks away.  We walked through old town and the high end
shopping district of Lyon – there are fashion shop show rooms from Paris
designers where they test market their latest designs.  We ended up on Place Bellecour at a wonderful
music store, Bellecour Musiques.

Pat found a beautiful pair of Moeck recorders to complete
her tonal set --- she found an Ebony alto recorder (lower registers) and a
lovely maple soprano.  She started
practicing with the band immediately to integrate them in for our Sunday
performance.
To close the day Saturday, Pat and DJ and I scoped out
restaurants within easy walking distance – Auntie Julia is having a lot of
trouble with her knee on this trip – it will be replaced in August.  We found L’assiette
du Marche at 21 Grande rue de Vaise, just across the river.  
Amazing does not begin to touch the wonders of the food at
this restaurant.  The limited menu gave
the band dishes based on rabbit and salmon. 
Both were spectacular.  But the
thrill of the evening was the executive chef. 
No English, yet we were able to communicate.  Hilarious. 
We had a taste test comparing his French sea salt to our hand gathered
Molokai sea salt.  It was a draw –
neither side conceding defeat.  We’ll go
back for another meal.
11 July 2015 – The whirlwind has been like a force four
tornado.  There has not been a moment to
reflect or write since I snuck in the last blog entry after the “big gig” in
Geneva.  It’s Saturday morning here and
we have two days off before the next gig. 
So here’s the story, working backward to Wednesday. 
The Aloha Bar
Friday night, Lyon France, old town, the Aloha Bar.  I still have to laugh, the Aloha Bar in Lyon
France.  The owner’s never been to
Hawaii.  But the theme is well done in
the bar.  Think back streets of
Waikiki.  Hole in the wall bar, but cool
– in a lot of ways it reminded me more of New York, east side of Manhattan,
where there are tons of little, themed bars. 
Nicola, the owner, sweet, enthusiastic guy.  He has the aloha spirit.
Here’s the bar before opening.
We were at the back of the bar area where we could have some
floor space for dancing.  Nice
setting.  The whole gig had been set up
by Lisa Arsac, Vice President and Events Coordinator for the American Club –
this was a pau hana (after work) informal gathering of the Club members as a
reception for the band.  Lisa has been
incredible, getting our time in Lyon organized. 
Here’s Lisa with the band – playing my guitar brilliantly
(wink, wink – she doesn’t play).  And
another shot with her very supportive husband Cyril.  
We started playing about 6:45, warm ups.  Nice small crowd.  I could explain the band and the Kai Moku
Journey.  Very attentive.  But the crowd rolled in about seven and we
went to town with livelier music and hula. 

The Aloha Bar packed full as the band got rolling.  We were playing acoustically, so pretty soon
we were overwhelmed with bar noise.  But
the crowd was more than attentive, in their own way.  They requested that we teach them some hula
and the party really rocked.
Here’s DJ teaching hula. 
The woman in the blue dress and glasses was trained as a belly dancer
and picked up hula like she was born to it. 
So fun to watch.
Great conversation with American Club folks after we
finished playing.  It was clear that a
huge portion of the aloha spirit had been served and taken in by this crowd.
Before the gig, our transit from our apartment to the Aloha
Bar had been a little rocky.  DJ, Bully,
Sue, and I walked.  We stopped at the
Music Center to pick up the small bass amplifier I had purchased for our Lyon
gigs earlier in the day and Bully carried it the rest of the way to the bar.  Back at the apartment we had bundled the rest
of the band and instruments into a Lyon Taxi – thank you Claire Point for
helping us negotiate this.  However, the
cab dropped off Pat with Auntie and Uncle at the wrong end of the block and
pointed them in the wrong direction at the bar end of the ride.  
Ever resourceful, Pat sat Auntie and Uncle down at a café
and searched out the gig.  While Auntie
was sitting in a chair at the closed bistro, the owner walked up and asked if
she needed anything, brought her water, and offered help.  Pat returned with everything scoped out and
also had some water while the three waited for the walkers to arrive.  
When Pat tried to leave a couple of Euros in appreciation of
the service, the owner said, “Non!” 
Jackie wouldn’t take our money. 
And having learned what we were there to do, she later showed up and
cheered us on at her competitor, the Aloha Bar. 

The story doesn’t end there. 
After the gig, the band decided on dinner at Jackie’s restaurant, El
Sombrero (9, rue Pizay).  The restaurant
has a Mexican chef and Jackie’s husband, the executive chef, is Cordon Bleu
trained. The food was beyond amazing. 
Here are a bunch of food pictures.Enchiladas in mole sauce
Chiles rellenos We retraced our steps back to the apartment and captured
great views of Lyon at night.  This is
one of the most photogenic cities in the world.
The taxi ride back to the apartment for Pat, Uncle, and
Auntie was a little more eventful.  One
way streets required a different route. 
The shortcut of the tunnel was “ferme” – closed – so the taxi headed
over the mountain.  What mountain, one
might ask.  One Pat did.  And they flew down a winding, narrow road, flashing
brights and waiting for oncoming traffic because it was essentially one
lane.  But, according to Pat, the views
were more than spectacular as they entered the Saône Valley from the mountain
top.
We debriefed in the comfort of our very posh flat on the
Saône.
Kanikapila at Claire’s House
Lyon is the home of Claire Point, her husband Sebastian, and
her three sons.  Claire is an important
person in my life and has been for more than a decade.  She arrived in my life as an intern at
Chelsea Group.  During her time in that
role she lived in our home in Itasca, Illinois. 
Many important life stories for Pat and me revolve around Claire.
Claire was so kind as to invite the entire band into her
home the evening we arrived in Lyon.  She
drove to our flat from her home 15 klicks upstream on the Saône in a van
borrowed from a neighbor.  We piled into
the van and felt like we’d gone home. 
Here’s Claire with the van and you’ll quickly see why we were so
comfortable.
A ’68 Ford Econoline, with wood panel interior and signage
offering its origin in Haliewa, Hawaii – a town on the North Shore of Oahu
where big wave surfing is life.  Claire,
you outdid yourself.  But the best was
yet to come.
The drive to Claire’s home took us up the Saône Valley
through beautiful scenery just as the sun was beginning to set.  Here’s a picture of the dashboard hula dancer
with the Saône, a barge, and the Saône Valley in the background.  
We arrived at Claire’s home in Neuville sur Saône as the
bells chimed on the half hour.  She
piloted the enormous van into the tiny back street and parked near her front
door.  The home was built in the late
1800s.  It is built of Saône river rock,
just like the garden wall below, but covered with hard plaster.  Sebastian,
Claire’s husband, has beautifully renovated the kitchen.  Through the kitchen we entered the amazing
courtyard.  
We played for our dinner. 
Claire and Sebastian, friends Oliver and Angela, and Claire’s cat paid
rapt attention as we played song after song. 
Sue danced.  Angela, trained in
classical ballet, tried to learn hula as she went, but finally just let the
music move her.
It was midnight before we landed back at the flat.  Pat had stayed home because of her cold and
deeply saddened to hear what she had missed.
Travel from Geneva to Lyon
Adventure. 
Daring.  Seductive Hawaiian
music.  Confusion.  Error. 
Recovery.  We had it all.
We had arranged to take the train from Geneva to Lyon.  JP, our harmonica player left us in Geneva to
return to Bristol and personal obligations. 
I dropped him at the airport after packing the equipment at the US
Mission and having a great chat with Ambassador Hamamoto.  
Pat and I dropped off the rest of the band at the train
station in downtown Geneva.  We had
difficulty exiting the parking garage because of misdirection about parking
fees.  Next, Pat and I go lost trying to
exit downtown Geneva for the airport.  We
took one wrong turn and entered one way hell. 
We were separated when Pat got caught in a turn lane and I went on to
the next intersection. We were both panicked and running out of time, driving
separate cars and with no communications since her phone was dead.
I wiggled through a new route that took me in an odd way
into the airport.  Pat was trapped in the
lake shore drive but then found her way to the route we knew from our commute
to our house in Segny.  With zero
communication some sort of odd magic happened and we ended up together as we
entered the Budget return gate.  Both of
us were greatly relieved.
But then we were on to the sprint to find the train from the
airport to the railway depot in downtown Geneva.  Signage was unhelpful.  Finally a kind Police Officer pointed us to
the train offices where a very, very sweet woman guided us to our proper
course.  We grabbed the next train and
made it just in time to join the rest of the band in boarding the train to the
French frontier where we were supposed to change trains to catch “Lyon Part
Dieu”.  
We missed the stop at Bellegarde.  Clueless. 
DJ and I ran to find the conductor. 
No English.  Again, magic happened
and two young women, Sisters Mattinson and Baggs, doing their missionary work in France (I am not making this
up there’s a picture of them below) appeared and translated.  Yes, the conductor explained, we could catch
a different Lyon Part Dieu train from the next station and arrive only a few
minutes later.
That left us on the platform at Aix-les-Bains for nearly an
hour.  Pat broke out her ukulele, then
Julia.  Pretty soon the platform was
alive with music, hula, and aloha.  Pat
taught this little girl how to strum the ukulele.
Spread the aloha.
Island Nations
Soundcheck seemed to draw the crowd down from security into
the garden.  The Ambassador spoke briefly
and then we exploded into Tewe Tewe.  The
party was on.  Over 200 representatives
of the smaller island nations gathered to coalesce around the band and the
spirit of aloha.  The Swiss halau was in
top form.  The audience, this time seated
in auditorium format on the well shaded lawn, responded to the energy of the set.

It was grand, dream-like: Wednesday afternoon, five to
seven, back at the garden on the campus of the US Mission in Geneva, the
security and staff treat us as part of the team.  It is a nice feeling.  We can hardly take a step without someone
thanking us for the beautiful music and bringing the spirit of aloha to Geneva
station.
The interaction with the audience was different in
nature.  At the end of the performance we
chatted with folks comfortably.  They were
full of questions and we did our best to answer.  It was clear that the music and hula touched
them with the spirit of aloha.
The band had spent the prior 24 hours recovering from the Tuesday
Independence Day celebration.  The high
temperatures on Tuesday had cooked the band – it turned out to be the hottest
day on record in Geneva, ever, any day, since records have been kept – which is
a long time.  Fortunately the pool at the
house had been cleaned and we were able to cool off a bit, even though the
water was near 90 degrees F.  It helped.
We had grand plans for our “time off” on Wednesday.  Mostly we slept or walked around in a
daze.  My fingers hurt from the long
guitar session the day before.  Bully’s
hand was cramping.  Pat’s voice was
rough.  Auntie was just exhausted.  DJ, somewhat bouncy, kept our spirits
agitated.  We prepared for the long day
ahead.
The day did not end with the performance for the Island
Nations.  Ambassador Hamamoto invited us
to her residence on Lake Geneva for a private dinner – just Pam and the
band.  And in that context, it was Pam,
not “The Ambassador”.  We kicked off our
shoes, talked in Pidgeon, and swapped stories of Hawaii.  
Most important, we got to play with Sandy, Pam’s beautiful
old dog.  Pat and I had met Sandy when we
had visited Pam at her California home a few years ago.  Sweet, sweet dog.  She so reminds me of Rufus.  I rolled on the floor playing with her.  Despite the elegant surroundings, it was a
perfectly comfortable thing to do.  But
then, that’s the tone Pam set.  
The meal was unforgettable. 
Pam’s chef at the residence, Hussein, is originally from Senegal.  Fabulous chef with a touch for flavors and
presentation unparalleled in my experience. 
Each course was a jewel in its own right and the combination sparkled
like a tiara.
We talked long into the night.  It was hard to say goodbye.  Pam is a gracious host and a good
friend.  Like the band, she lives aloha.  Our country is fortunate to have someone with
such talent and substance in our service.



8 July 2015 – We’re all recovering
from a natural high.  Buoyed by a huge
dose of the spirit of aloha, we all stayed up into the night talking through
the excitement and joy of a hugely successful performance for the US Mission to
the United Nations yesterday.  Here's the video
From the Ambassador – Pam Hamamoto: feedback from the
audience was that the gathered 1,200 or so diplomats from over 170 countries had
an overwhelming positive response to the combination of her speech on spreading
the spirit of aloha and the music and dance we brought to the event.  A celebration of the US Independence Day
yielded not the usual jingoism but instead a spirit of global cooperation to
solve the pressing problems we all know from the world news.
This is what Pam had asked us to do and we did it.  
Plus it was a lot of fun. 

We performed in three sets. 
The first set was the welcome.  We
played while the participants in the event passed through the beautifully done
security process and through the reception line.  Four Ambassadors – Pam is head of station –
greeted the guests.  Our music and the
dancing of the Swiss halau brought them into the heart of the event.
Once the guests were all in and security closed the gates,
the ceremony celebrating the birth of the United States was underway.  A Marine Honor Guard presented the
colors.  A quartet of State Department
officials from the Geneva Mission provided a brilliant rendition of the Star
Spangled Banner.  It brought tears to our
eyes – a magical interpretation hauntingly performed in soaring harmonies.
Pam’s speech equally reached the highest levels of
diplomatic presentation.  From the band’s
perspective we were most honored by this: Last year Pam made a commitment to
bring the spirit of aloha to her work with the UN in Geneva; this year she
brought us, as the flesh and blood embodiment of that spirit, as an emblem of
how that spirit is being realized.  Na
Ohana Hoaloha was presented to the world as the living embodiment of the Spirit
of Aloha.
This is a duty we do not take lightly.  And in the second set we demonstrated how, through
international cooperation with a Swiss hula halau, the musical and dance
heritage of Hawaii could be shared with everyone.  Plus we were ON!  
The weather did not make this easy.  The temperature crossed 40 degrees C (100+
degrees F) and there was no wind.  Bully
became dizzy.  Auntie lost her
place.  All of us dripped with
sweat.  But we persisted.  And we performed at the top of our game.  
The coordination with the Swiss began in the fall of
2014.  Their halau sent representatives
to Molokai in early February to coordinate. 
But it was not until July 6th that we were able to practice together.  No one in the audience would have guessed
that.  The flow of the program and
quality of song and dance presented to the audience was nearly flawless.
We opened with a song from our new album, Tewe Tewe.  Our arrangement combines chant, powerful ipu
rhythms, and intense starts of the vocal segments.  There were cheers among the audience.  The Swiss followed that with some beautiful
kahiko (ancient) hula danced to their own chants and ipu.  
We restarted with a song that will be on our next album,
Mokio Sunrise.  That was followed by
Green Rose Hula.  Our arrangement of the
song alternates full band and acapella versions of the verse.  The Swiss danced and played ipu as they did –
the combination through the acapella verses created an impression of a cross
between kahiko and auana that was very compelling.  Again, huge audience response.
We finally took a break after the second set and grabbed a
light lunch from what was left of the buffet. 
Standing in the shade of the trees was a real relief after the stage
heat.
The third set was more of a real party for us.  We kicked it off with teaching a bunch of
very enthusiastic folks how to do the Hukilau, an easy hula taught by DJ with
support from Sue and the Swiss halau. 
That was followed by Hawaiian Hoki-poki. 
We had three ambassadors up dancing – led by Pam.  Laughter filled the grounds.  A childlike joy filled the hearts of all.
Days like this are not just rare.  We have reached the pinnacle of the Kai Moku
Journey.  Now we will wind our way down
the mountain as we spread a little more aloha in Geneva and then on to Lyon to
share some more.
Watch this space…
6 July 2015 – We made it to Geneva.  Thanks to help from JP and his son Michael, the
departure went smoothly from Bristol, England. 
Yesterday, which was Sunday the 5th, we had an early, early
start.  We left JP’s house a little
before 4am.  
The dawn trip through the English countryside was
beautiful.  The farms surrounding Bristol
were just waking up.  The light gave a
gold tint to the crops and windrows shedding precious insight into the spirit
of the land.  Farm homes and out buildings,
many from three, four, and five centuries past, took on a warmth that bespoke
the energy of their people.
JP herded our band of cats through the early morning
crowds.  His experience as a world traveler
shone through – kindness to the harried EasyJet staff was reciprocated with
easy passage for us.  Pat’s arrangement
were again flawless.
Here’s a picture of our row of musicians on the EasyJet
Plane
Martin, our friend from the US Mission in Geneva, met us at
the baggage claim once we landed.  This
was a purely volunteer effort on Martin’s part – he took time away from his
visiting family to greet us.  He took up
JP’s role and used his diplomatic credentials to smooth our way.  Martin, if you recall, is a top notch bass
player.  He and Bully bonded over the
ukulele bass and their preferences in music. 
THANK YOU, Martin!
Soon enough we were rolling through the French countryside
on our way to the home we rented in Segny (“Sig-Knee”).  Sundays are quiet days in rural France.  The only place open for lunch was an American
bistro known throughout the world as McDonalds. 
We munched on French Micky-D food while we waited for the property
manager to open the house.  The food was
good.  I had a goat cheese wrap that was
beyond delicious and the best thing I remember eating at a McDonalds.
The house turned out to be just as amazing as we
imagined.  We quickly divvied up sleeping
space and everyone was comfortable.  The
heat is the only problem.  They had
warned us as we landed that the temperature would be 38.  That’s in degrees C.  Read 99 in degrees F.  Killa.
The view from the house
The temperature came down in the evening, heading for the
mid 20s – 70-ish.  We went out to dinner
at one of the few places open and had a wonderful experience.  With JP speaking French, seemingly fluently,
we had an easy time of picking great menu items and getting great services from
a very friendly staff.  
Here’s a picture of the 282 Bistro
Monday is the start of practice for the BIG DAY.  Weather report says sunny, but HOT, HOT,
HOT.  But it was about 72 at breakfast and we had a beautiful view of the mountains, too.The outdoor event on Tuesday will
likely be in 38+ (100+) degree weather. 
Good thing we’re tough from our hot stage at Paddlers’ Inn on Molokai,
but it sure would have been nice for us to play in typical Geneva summer
weather of 75 and sunny.  Never let a
little thing like that get in the way of a good time, though.
Watch this space!
4 July 2015 – Happy Birthday America!  And Happy Birthday Hannah Parsons – JP’s
beautiful granddaughter.  We’re still
staying with Michael and his family in Bristol England.  Here's the house with Pat going in the walk.We have our second gig tonight at the
Victoria Pub.
Here’s a picture of the Victoria Pub, Bully keeping it standing
The owner saw us play at the Duck and almost instantly set
up for us to play the Saturday night crowd at her place.  Here’s the poster she developed (and signed, “with
much love, Rhone”) for us.
Rhona fed us extremely well. 
The food at the Victoria is excellent. 
We had several different entrees among us and everyone loved their
choices.  Here’s a shot of pub food.
Then it was time to play and play we did.  Here’s a shot of DJ, Julia, and Pat getting
settled into the nicely decorated impromptu stage Rhona put together for us.
What a night!  Folks
who had seen us at the Duck started showing up. 
The place packed up.  We already
have Na Ohana Hoaloha groupies in Bristol England!  One couple there was so enthused they invited
us to come back next year to play for their wedding.  Another couple, with the woman due with a
baby girl at any moment, want to visit and consider moving to Hawaii after the
experience.  She even danced the hula
when DJ taught the Hukilau – but threatened to have her baby right then and
there!
4 July 2015 – A day of touring with our intrepid guide, Michael Parsons.  Not only is he an incredible host for our visit to Bristol, he is a brilliant tour guide.  Michael is a highly skilled and qualified buildings expert.  He gave us an amazing perspective on the history of Bristol through its architecture.  
Here is Michael with the Transit Van that JP rented to take us around England



The bridge over the Avon Gorge is truly a wonder.  Designed in 1831, it continues today to link the commercial and residential centers of Bristol.  It is an elegant beauty.  
Here is a picture of the bridge




Michael snapped a shot of us as we posed at the beginning of the bridge walkway.  DJ is on the left, Uncle Herb next, then Pat, Sue, and finally George on the right.At the bridge crossing there is a rock formation that has been worn by use into a very clever slide.  Our host demonstrated his boyish character by sliding down it.  But it was Sue that had requested that we visit it.  We were all stunned as Sue showed the tomboy in her Angel-hula dancer presence and bounced down the rough, rocky slide, worn to shiny by all the little boys’ butts that preceded her.
Here’s a picture of Sue sliding down the cliffs of the Avon Gorge.



We’re off shortly to play our second gig.  I’m excited to be getting ready to head to Geneva, too.
Watch this space!

3 July 2015 – The Black Swan Pub (known to the regulars as
the Dirty Duck, or just the Duck) will never be the same after the hula lesson
and the closing circle.  The Aloha Spirit
was palpable by the end of our performance. 
Here’s video of Sue inspiring the pub crowd to take up hula.
Joining us for the evening was JP’s grandson Joshua.  He got the crowd into sing-along mode with a
hit from the 1960s by the Monkeys called “I’m a Believer”.  Here’s a clip of Joshua leading the crowd in
that song.
The session ended with a request from the audience for two
things – a simple hula that DJ could teach them and for us to sing the song Hukilau.  We combined the two requests and DJ taught
about ten or so folks how to dance the Hukilau while the band played it once
slowly for teaching purposes and then once up to full speed.  What a blast. 
They were quick learners!
The evening ended with a request from the owner of a nearby
pub to play Saturday night at her place. 

More to come…. Watch this space!

2 July 2015 – We’re in England now,
getting ready for our first pub gig.  We
arrived yesterday, about 25 hours from the time we got going on Oahu and more
than 40 hours from the time we left Molokai. 
The whole band was together for the flight across the country and the
Atlantic.  
Here’s our band upon arrival at Heathrow in London



Our Harmonica Player, JP (John Parsons), and his grandson
Joshua (at right in photo above) picked us up in a 14-passenger Transit Van and ferried us to Bristol.  There we were warmly welcomed by Joshua’s
parents, Michael and Natasha, and his sister Hannah.  JP, ever the proud grandpa, shepherded us
around the town.
Here’s the view from the “tower room” at Michael’s home,
where Pat and I found a comfortable bed waiting for our worn and jetlagged
selves.


We spent an hour at the pub where we’ll play tonight.  JP’s friend Chris and a group of pub goers
welcomed us.  The sign out front let
everyone know that tonight (Thursday, July 2) will be Hawaiian night with live
music all the way from the Islands.
Joshua, JP, and Michael fed us a marvelous pasta dinner and
we all retired to sleep off the travel.
Watch this space!
30 June 2015 – Aloha Molokai and Hawaii Nei!  





We had a great send off by Shari and the staff of the
Admirals Club in Honolulu.  They are old
friends.  Gotta mention Armie
Pilicara-Woods, who saved our butts on check-in details, but wasn’t there to
see us off.  And to Shari for working her
magic to make seating better than expected.


We’re across the Pacific now, at the LAX Admirals Club.  We took over a corner of the Club and a
friendly French speaking person took a picture of the whole band.



We’re all doing well and in good spirits.
Watch this space

30 June 2015 – We’ll be boarding the plane at Honolulu
International to Heathrow in just a few hours now.  It was an eventful and important day
today.  Pat, Bully, and I left topside
Molokai at about 1:30 pm and began our Kai Moku Journey with a short plane ride
to Kalaupapa, the former Leper Colony and site of the miracles of Saint Damien
and Saint Marianne.  
Kalaupapa comes into
view


The final approach to
the landing strip at Kalaupapa


Here’s a picture of
the three of us at the Kalaupapa airport terminal


The plane from Molokai is a luxurious ride.  We flew Mokulele, one of my favorite airlines
of all time.  Captain Christian and
co-pilot Bonny brought us in on the tiny runway at the edge of the ocean on
this most isolated of peninsulas in the world. 

Captain Christian and
co-pilot Bonny with Pat and Bully in front of their plane


The terminal at
Kalaupapa


We’re still wrapping up details as I write this.  Bully is resting on the futon in my Kailua
apartment on Oahu – yes, we made it on the first leg of our journey.  


29 June 2015 -- It is official, after our Geneva gigs, we are playing at the Aloha Bar in Lyon, France.  Come join us at 7 pm on 10 July 2015!  It will also be a reception for the American Club of Lyon.  The public is welcome.
Here is the invitation:



Special Hawaiian
Happy Hour
Aloha!  Come out and join us for a
special Hawaiian Happy Hour
Let’s get together for
some exotic drinks and island atmosphere while enjoying an authentic
Hawaiian music and dance
performance by Na Ohana Noaloha (A Family of Friends)
The Aloha bar is also offering
ACL members a 
Happy Hour drink special
of Hawaiian beer 5€ ( 7€ normally), 
and all cocktails 8€ (9€ or 10€
normally)
When: Friday, July 10th at 6:30 pm (band starting at 7pm)
Where: Aloha Bar, 4 rue
Pizay, Lyon 69001

Watch this space...

28 June 2015 – Frantic, frantic,
frantic.  A million more things to do
before we leave and that is TOMORROW! 
Really, we’re in great shape thanks to Pat’s incredible organizational
skills.  It is more like a million
details to be cleared up, not a million important things to do.  
Pat works here with Julia on tailoring her costume --


The band met again yesterday and went over all of the arrangements.



Everyone flies over to Honolulu tomorrow, Monday, June 29th,
and gets set for the early departure on Tuesday.  We’re all staying with family or friends –
THANK YOU for your continuing support and willingness to get up before dawn to
see us off.  We rendezvous at HNL between
4:45 and 5:00 am on Tuesday morning.  And
then… we’re leaving on a jet plane…
Today is our last regular weekly performance at Paddlers’
Inn before we head into the wild blue yonder. 
We’ve picked out songs from the tour book and we’ll use the performance
as a practice of sorts.  Should be a good
send-off with all of our regulars there to cheer us on.
Bully has been hanging with his other musician friends and
says that they are happy to see us be, as they call it, “ambassadors for
Molokai”.  Thanks, guys, and proud to do
it.
We’re still in pre-release for our CD.  We’ve had some good feedback and I got the CD
into the hands of Derrek Malama, a great DJ who does his “Kanekapila Sunday”
every week on Hawaii Public Radio – great show. 
He’s also the host of Morning Edition on HPR, so you may have heard his
voice if you are an NPR freak like me.  I’m
hoping Derrek likes a few cuts and gives us some air time.  Thanks to Deane Neubauer – regular supporter and
fan of ours – for making the introduction to Derrek.
For you on-line music buyers, we’re up on iTunes now, as
well as CDbaby.  Look for Na
Ohana Hoaloha: LIVE!
Well, time to pull everything together for this
performance.  Aloha no.
Watch this space…

22 June 2015 – Things spinning faster
and faster, so many moving parts, but some things are locking down, too.  
Number one best news: the case full of instruments we
shipped to the US Mission in Geneva is there, has passed through customs, and
is now in the trusted hands of Martin The Bass Player (see 17 June entry).  
Number two best news: Na Ohana Hoalaoha: LIVE! is in hand,
including the CD in beautiful DigiPaks, the CDbaby Digital Download Cards for
the diplomats, and our lovely posters.  
Proof that it is real:


We plopped a CD in a few different players and the sound is
GREAT.  Thank you Bully, thank you
DiscMakers.  And for you on-line music
buyers, you’ll be finding the album on Amazon, iTunes, and elsewhere over the
next few days.  
If you want it RIGHT NOW, you can just click over to http://cdbaby.com/cd/naohanahoaloha
We’ve developed our pre-release approach and have a draft of
our launch events in Europe and in the US. 
For those of you who have done this before, we are open to tips on
effective kick-off efforts.
The European launch will, of course, be the July event in
Geneva, were “world-wide distribution” will earn its name.  We will hand CDbaby Digital Download Card of Na Ohana
Hoaloha: LIVE! to representatives
of over 170 nations while they listen to us play.  
The US Launch will take place upon our triumphant return to
Paddlers Inn on Molokai.  We’re
scheduling it for Sunday, July 19th. 
It’s going to be a blast.  We’ll
show videos and photos from our European Tour. 
The State Department will be filming our programs in Geneva and they
have offered to share.  We’ll play a
little of the music, talk story, and soak in the good vibes.
Watch this space!


17 June 2015 – Things are spinning up
pretty fast now.  Our new album, Na
Ohana Hoaloha: LIVE! Launched in digital download form on Sunday and is
available at http://cdbaby.com/cd/naohanahoaloha
and looks great and sounds great.  You can
listen to samplings of the music at that site and buy if you like – one song at
a time or the whole shootin’ match.  
Our instruments shipped from Molokai, headed for Geneva
Switzerland on Tuesday (June 16).  Pat
and George stayed up ‘til past midnight packing the case and doing the shipping
paperwork.  Both talked to Martin in
shipping and receiving at the US Mission to the United Nations in Geneva to
make the arrangements for their receipt. 

So cool, turns out Martin has played bass professionally, so
he was totally understanding of our trepidation at shipping our favorite instruments!  They are slated to arrive in Geneva on June
23rd.  Martin will check them
out and make sure everything is playable. 
We’re much more comfortable having talked to Martin.
Here are two pictures of Martin -- the manager of the shipping and receiving activities at the US Mission in Geneva --  as I said, cool...

            We heard back from our contact at the American Club of Lyon,
France, too.  Lisa, a Vice President of
the Club and an events coordinator, is setting up a reception at the Aloha Bar
in Lyon – can you believe it a Hawaiian themed bar in Lyon France!
Here’s the funny part -- we had checked their Facebook page
and found the Aloha Bar was forced to close on June 9th for
structural repairs to their building.  We
were bummed.  On Sunday the band talked
about offering to do some sort of fundraiser to help them back on their
feet.  But lo, and much to our surprise,
they are already back in business.
So it looks like really cool gigs in three countries – England
(Bristol), Switzerland (Geneva), and France (Lyon).  Still looking for more gigs – retirement center
or something – in Lyon, too.
Watch this space...

14 June 2015 -- The date of the departure from Molokai grows closer.  And closer.   We've locked in virtually all of our travel arrangements now.  Tomorrow we ship our instruments to the US Mission to the UN in Geneva.  The band spent all day yesterday going over progress and plans.


You'll see that ukuleles are in hand.  They are like teddy bears or blankies -- if you remember Linus from the Peanuts gang.  


Virtually every detail of our travel
plans is locked down now – thank you Pat. 
You can see the pages with golden color on them – these are our play
lists for the Geneva performances.  All
of these are locked in now too.
We’ve made a lot of accommodations to reduce the cost of the
trip. One really good example is the
U-bass (an ukulele set up like a bass guitar). We found it costs about ¼ as much to buy Bully
a U-bass than to ship his beautiful Modulus electric bass to and from
Geneva.  Bully is extremely happy with
the new little bass, which sounds just like a stand-up bass when
amplified.  He’s even happier now that we
have installed Aquila “red” strings, like we use on all of our regular
ukuleles.  They have a smooth and gentle
touch.  


Our CD is in the final stages of production at Discmakers
with a ship date of June 16th – this coming Tuesday.  The electronic version of the CD is already
up on CDbaby and will launch on Amazon and iTunes in a week or so.  Check it out -- http://cdbaby.com/cd/naohanahoaloha
and read the album notes on that site.  
Watch this space…

The Kai Moku Journey Kai Moku means the changing tide in Hawaiian.  With your help, our band, Na Ohana Hoaloha (translation: Family of Friends) will bring a tide of aloha to the international diplomatic community at the United Nations in Geneva, Switzerland this July.  We are still about $20,000 short of the funds we need to make this a comfortable trip for the band.  Here's how your contribution will help:

Complete the production of our "Na Ohana Hoaloha: LIVE!" album to provide a lasting statement of aloha in our songs
Support the logistical needs of the band, which have proven much more costly than estimated
Demonstrate your aloha to the world (and get a PERK if you like)

Please make your contribution on this page -- and you can select a PERK at the same time.  
**********
Read on for a fuller explanation of the journey.  For a deeper dive, see and listen to our first indiegogo campaign at --


http://igg.me/at/NOHMKK/x/10072843





How We Got Here
US Ambassador Pamela Hamamoto in her speech to the US Independence Day celebration last year remarked: "I thought long and hard about how best to bring the aloha spirit all the way 
from Hawaii, 7,700 miles — or I should say, 12,000 kilometers! – and spread it 
around Geneva, the UN, and all the international organizations. "  She chose to bring our little band from the island of Molokai, Hawaii, to this year's celebration to do just that.
This is our second campaign to raise funding for Kai Moku.  Our first effort, which closed on May 2nd,  achieved 26% (about $10,000) of our goal of $35,000.  
Over 1,250 people looked at, listened to, and read about Kai Moku  at http://igg.me/at/NOHMKK/x/10072843

  Have a look and find out why they contributed.
We're opening this site to continue our fund raising efforts.  We hope to more than achieve our modest goal, which will allow us to keep the site open into the future.  We plan to share photos, descriptions, and video from the Kai Moku journey as it happens.  But we still need your help.
   Watch the Journey Unfold
 


Recording for the Tour
The band made a commitment to provide a recording of our songs to commemorate the performance for the UN crowd.    Creating and producing that album has been quite an adventure.  For one thing, the CD project has had a name change.  Now it is "Na Ohana Hoaloha: LIVE!"  We've completed the mixing and mastering, the graphics, and the supporting information and we've reviewed the proofs from our production house: we're on target to deliver the CD in Geneva!
Na
Ohana Hoaloha shifted its CD plan to a set of covers of traditional and
contemporary Hawaiian music.  The new
plan is based on our live program performances recorded every Sunday at Paddler’s
Inn and Restaurant on the island of Molokai.

The Kai Moku Album Notes


Na Ohana Hoaloha: LIVE! … Album Notes on CD Baby:
Take a little trip to
the island of Moloka'i. Na Ohana Hoaloha has drawn well over 10,000 audience
members to its Sunday afternoon performances of Hawaiian music and hula over
the past ten years. Here is your chance to hear some of our great performance
time captured live and in full audio color.
The album opens with a
rousing version of "Tewe Tewe", a classic Hawaiian song performed
here in part chant, part chorus. Heavy on the rhythm of the islands, you can
understand, even without knowing the Hawaiian language, that this song about
catching fish isn't just about fishing. Squirming, squirming. Is that about
fish or...
An old song reborn,
the next track is "Green Rose Hula". Only Na Ohana Hoaloha can pull
off this combination of rapid guitar work balanced against a cappella runs of
each verse. Harmonies abound.
"Hi'ilawe",
a classic of the Hawaiian scene, is done here in a version for which beautiful
choreography has been developed by band member and kumu hula (teacher or master
of hula) DJ Pelekai. A warm version or the song, DJ's beautiful voice lets it
paint a picture of the waterfalls at Hi'ilawe while portraying the emotions of
two lovers as they learn of the gossip flying around about them.
"Holoholo"
in Hawaiian is similar to the idea of walkabout in Australia. "Holoholo
Fun" is an original song by band member George Benda and was inspired by
his dog Rufus, a Golden Retriever that was the neighborhood dog ambassador.
Rufus had a "happy dance" as he walked that is captured in the energy
and bounce of this song.
"Hula 'O
Ma

story:
Für Deutsch hier klicken

Sistanagila is a music group consisting of Iranian and Israeli Musicians
based in Berlin Germany. 
We communicate through music. 

**** Even though we understand we will not reach our goal, we promise we will record the CD in any case. We will gain more funding through our concerts and make pre-odrering lists for CDs. We will make this happen! Sistanagila*****

The project is a reaction to the negative messages spread by both
governments and demonstrates that there is an alternative to hatred and fear, an authentic voice.

We have been playing concerts all around Germany in the last 2 years and are
now going towards our next goal- recording our first CD.

That's where we need you. If you order a CD now we both get something from
it, we get the funding to record the CD, you get a CD with our music.

If you feel like being a bigger supporter just choose a reward from the
rewards on the right or fill in a free different amount in the donation field.
Any donation is accepted gives us a warm feeling in our heart knowing that
people stand behind this idea. 

Please forward this website to your friends and colleagues. We can not do this alone we need your help!


What music style do SISTANAGILA play?

Our music could be categorised as world music. It is a Fusion of a few
elements: folk music, improvisation and Jazz.
We took old Jewish folk music and old Persian folk music and arranged them
in a modern way. Each musician brought his input to the pieces, so the
Jewish as well as the Persian pieces are influenced by both cultures- a Fusion.
In addition we composed new pieces for the ensemble based on Persian and
Jewish elements.

But what do SISTANAGILA need the money for?

We decided not to go for a small home-made production, since we want to
reach as many people as possible and offer a high level product. 
We chose the 2 time Echo (German Grammy) winner Studio Lowswing located in
Berlin.

Recording in a professional studio is expensive and then comes the editing
of the music and  the mixing. After the CD is finished, we will need to create the booklet with a professional graphic artist, print the CDs, send it to you and of course pay indiegogo their percentage.

Our References:

NPR 

http://www.npr.org/blogs/parallels/2014/11/12/363517234/the-rare-place-where-israelis-and-iranians-play-together

The Christian Science Monitor 

http://www.csmonitor.com/World/Europe/2014/0928/Iranians-and-Israelis-find-an-unlikely-musical-detente-in-Germany

Der Tagesspiegel (German)

http://www.tagesspiegel.de/kultur/sistanagila-ein-lied-kann-eine-bruecke-sein/9210468.html

Bayerischer Rundfunk (German)

http://www.br.de/radio/b5-aktuell/sendungen/interkulturelles-magazin/sistanagila-100.html

Hessischer Rundfunk (German)

http://www.diapod.de/cms/?p=30492

World music festival in Kassel(German)

http://www.hna.de/nachrichten/kultur/musik-symbolkraft-sistanagila-beim-weltmusikfestival-3526745.html


For English text click here

Sistanagila ist ein iranisch-israelisches Ensemble aus Berlin. 


Das Projekt ist eine Reaktion auf die feindselige und kriegstreiberische Rhetorik der Regierungen und möchte damit eine Alternative zu aktuellen von Hass erfüllten Spannungen präsentieren, eine authentische Stimme auf Grundlage einer künstlerischen Zusammenarbeit.

Wir sind seit zwei Jahren aktiv und haben in dieser Zeit zahlreiche Konzerte in ganz Deutschland mit großem Erfolg absolviert. Jetzt stehen wir vor unserem nächsten Ziel und wollen unsere erste CD aufnehmen.

Und hier brauchen wir EUCH. Wenn IHR eine CD bestellt, haben wir beide etwas davon: wir können unsere CD aufnehmen und IHR bekommt die CD mit unserer Musik.

Wenn IHR denkt, dass ihr unser Fan werden und damit auch diese Idee unterstützen möchtet, wählt einfach eines unserer Dankeschön-Pakete auf der rechten Seite aus. (hier clicken um die Pakete zu sehen)

Ihr könnt natürlich auch einfach einen Betrag im Spende-Feld eintragen.

Jede Spende wird gerne angenommen und lässt uns mit einem warmen Gefühl in unserem Herzen wissen, dass Menschen hinter dieser Idee stehen.

Bitte leitet diese Website an eure Freunde und Kollegen weiter. Wir brauchen eure Hilfe!

Was ist der Musikstil von SISTANAGILA?

Unsere Musik könnte als Weltmusik bezeichnet werden. Es ist eine Fusion von verschiedenen Elementen aus traditioneller Volksmusik, Improvisation und Jazz.

Wir nehmen alte jüdische und persische Volksmusik und arrangieren sie auf eine moderne Art und Weise. Der musikalische Hintergrund jedes Musikers fließt natürlich in unsere Musik ein, so dass sowohl die Jüdischen als auch die Persischen Stücke von beiden KULTUREN beeinflusst sind - eine Fusion im wahrsten Sinne.

Darüber hinaus haben wir zusammen neue Stücke basierend auf Persischen und Jüdischen Elementen für das Ensemble komponiert.

Aber wofür braucht SISTANAGILA das ganze Geld?

Wir haben uns entschieden, keine kleine hausgemachte Produktion zu machen, weil wir die Menschen auf der ganzen Welt erreichen und denen ein qualitatives Produkt anbieten wollen.

Deswegen haben wir uns für das Studio Lowswing in Berlin entschieden, das schon zweimal mit seinen Produktionen den Echo erhalten hat.

Eine Aufnahme in einem hochprofessionellen Studio ist teuer und dann kommt noch die Bearbeitung der Musik und die Abmischung dazu.

Nachdem die CD fertig ist, möchten wir das Booklet von einem professionellen Grafiker gestalten lassen, die CDs drucken und den Anteil von Indiegogo bezahlen.

Und dann schicken wir Ihnen unsere neue CD zu!

Sistanagila in der Presse:

Der Tagesspiegel

http://www.tagesspiegel.de/kultur/sistanagila-ein-lied-kann-eine-bruecke-sein/9210468.html

Bayerischer Rundfunk

http://www.br.de/radio/b5-aktuell/sendungen/interkulturelles-magazin/sistanagila-100.html

Hessischer Rundfunk

http://www.diapod.de/cms/?p=30492

Rezension zum Konzert auf dem Weltmusikfestival in Kassel

http://www.hna.de/nachrichten/kultur/musik-symbolkraft-sistanagila-beim-weltmusikfestival-3526745.html

NPR (English)

http://www.npr.org/blogs/parallels/2014/11/12/363517234/the-rare-place-where-israelis-and-iranians-play-together

The Christian Science Monitor (English)

http://www.csmonitor.com/World/Europe/2014/0928/Iranians-and-Israelis-find-an-unlikely-musical-detente-in-Germany

story:
*UPDATE (7/7): Release July 28th!

The debut album 'Awkward & Depressed' will be out in 3 weeks! A link to the pre-order will be up this weekend, and the first single "Your Validation" can be seen on my YouTube channel next Friday. Thank you for your patience, the delays were necessary and I am VERY happy with how everything turned out!

1. Average Joe
2. Your Validation
3. Mathematical
4. Great Again
5. Mumble
6. Lysergide
7. Seven (Sunny Day Real Estate cover)
8. Peev Shalpatine
9. Weebi Fm
10. Cut the Cord (featuring Hotel Books)
11. United We Skramz
12. Ohio Is for Emo Kids
13. Pink Wednesday

The winner of the contest is David Leøng, a photographer based in San Francisco. There were 263 contestants with over 1,000 photo submissions, and it was very difficult finding the right one. Backers will receive their merch within a couple days of the July 28th release (international orders might take a few days longer). This weekend is your LAST CHANCE to change your shipping address through Indiegogo if you've moved. If you selected the "Skype Date" perk, I will be sending you an email very soon. The shout out video will be up in August.

*UPDATE (4/20): 132% funded!

*UPDATE (3/23): 100% funded!

*UPDATE (3/20): I've added a new batch of signed posters, only 150 available!

*UPDATE (3/18): 75% funded! We've made changes to the $25 T-shirt designs.

*UPDATE (3/12): 50% funded!

STORY: What is this all about?

Canadian Softball is an emo band from Milwaukee, Wisconsin. Like the many other bands signed to the totally-not-fake label Chodezilla Records (Sunrise Skater Kids, Amidst The Grave's Demons, etc.), CaSo has established themselves as one of the satirecore scene's finest acts. My recent crowdfunded projects Beating A Dead Horse, Friendville and Space Zombies EP really got me hooked on comedy music, and I don't plan on stopping soon. To keep things short, here are some informative bullet points...

  • We are raising $20,000 for this release.
  • These are NOT donations, since every contribution gets a perk.
  • If the goal is not met within 30 days, the project will be CANCELLED.
  • You will not be charged and can keep your money if this occurs.
  • If we surpass $30,000, I will take this band on a LIVE TOUR.
  • The songs will be professionally produced by Johnny Franck.
  • The pizza memelord himself Jarrod Alonge will be doing vocals.
  • This album could be ready for release as early as April 2017.

This project can only be as good as the amount it raises. More money means better production value, better rewards, better music videos and potentially extra songs.

PERKS: What do I get?

The perks (or rewards) of this crowdfunding campaign are divided into separate tiers based on how much you contribute. Because this is a Fixed Funding Indiegogo project, you will NOT be charged unless the final $20,000 goal is achieved. It's all-or-nothing, so don't worry about not getting anything in return.

  • $1 perk: Your name in a shout-out video! All contributors get this.
  • $5 perk: A signed 18x24" CaSo poster! *LIMITED*
  • $10 perk: Digital download on release date!
  • $15 perk: Physical CD and digital download!
  • $25 perk: T-shirt and digital download!
  • $35 perk: Strapback hat and digital download!
  • $50 perk: T-shirt, strapback, CD, download and stickers!
  • $65 perk: A massive, patriotic CaSo wall flag!**
  • $75 perk: Skype in during a live CaSo recording session!**
  • $100 perk: Personal Skype conversation and 48x48" wall flag!**
  • $250 perk: I will bake a tater tot hotdish for you and your friends!***
  • $1,000 perk: Tater tot hotdish party, anywhere in the USA!***
  • $1,000,000,000 perk: I will literally become Jared Dines!***

**Includes T-shirt, strapback hat, physical CD, download and stickers.

***Includes EVERY PERK listed before it (except the poster).

NOTE: Shipping is free for the United States, $5 for both Canada and Mexico, and $10 for every other international country. If you wish to customize a perk, email me HERE.

STRETCH GOALS: What if you raise over $20,000?

Unlike Sunrise Skater Kids, I am the vocalist of Canadian Softball. Because of this happy coincidence, I will literally take the band on a live house show tour if I can get enough money to fund such a thing. If you want to see music videos, merch upgrades or perhaps extra songs, get your friends in on the campaign and help us exceed our stretch goals!

  • $20,000: Campaign success, album funded!
  • $30,000: I will take Canadian Softball on a house show tour. Seriously.
  • $35,000: The house show tour could become a legit venue tour.
  • $50,000: Guess I'll have to record another album or something.
  • $100,000: I will eat my own foot and put the video on YouTube.
 

BUDGET: Why do you need $20,000?

As a relatively low-profile YouTuber, I make a humble income. Doing something like this is more expensive than you would think, and $20,000 is actually a pretty low amount for how much money I'll be forced to dish out. Although I surpassed BOTH budgets for my last two crowdfunding campaigns, I still ran out and used some of my own money (merch fulfillment alone for Friendville was $14,000). Luckily, it all worked out financially and I'm not living on the streets.

Remember that your contributions are NOT donations. Every amount starting at $1 gets you perk, so you're essentially just pre-ordering an album or merch. Although production value is very important to me, keep in mind that not all of the $20,000 would be used for actual music production. Here are the things that I need to pay for in order to make this Canadian Softball release happen...

  • Recording, mixing & mastering: $6,000
  • Media (artwork, videos, etc.): $1,500
  • Online distribution & publishing: $250
  • Perk fulfilment: $5,000 to $10,000
  • Travel costs: $200 to $400
  • Indiegogo & PayPal fees: $1,000
  • Estimated taxes: $2,000 to $4,000
  • Other potential costs: $500

NOTE: Ultimately, ALL money raised goes back into my music somehow.

 

SUPPORT: How else can I help?

Some of you are poor as shit (but somehow still have access to the internet). If you are unable to contribute, you can still help by spreading the word and telling your friends about the campaign. Here are some things you can do...

  • Tell your friends about Canadian Softball and this new project.
  • Post the campaign video to Facebook, Twitter and Tumblr.
  • Like the Canadian Softball page on Facebook.
  • Subscribe to my YouTube channel. Lots of weird things on there.
  • Follow me on social media to like/share/retweet my garbage.
  • Sell drugs and give me a percentage of your profits.

If you have questions about anything that weren't made clear by this page, you can always send me an email HERE.

Because this is a Fixed Funding Indiegogo project, you will NOT be charged unless the final $20,000 goal is achieved. It's all-or-nothing, so don't worry about not getting anything in return.

$1 perk: Your name in a shout-out video! All contributors get this.

$5 perk: A signed 18x24" CaSo poster! *LIMITED*


$10 perk: Digital download on release date!

$15 perk: Physical CD and digital download!

$25 perk: T-shirt and digital download!

$35 perk: Strapback hat and digital download!

$50 perk: T-shirt, strapback, CD, download and stickers!

$65 perk: A massive, patriotic CaSo wall flag!**

$75 perk: Skype in during a live CaSo recording session!**

$100 perk: Personal Skype conversation and 48x48" wall flag!**

$250 perk: I will bake a tater tot hotdish for you and your friends!***

$1,000 perk: Tater tot hotdish party, anywhere in the USA!***

$1,000,000,000 perk: I will literally become Jared Dines!***
**Includes T-shirt, strapback hat, physical CD, download and stickers.***Includes EVERY PERK listed before it (except the poster).NOTE: Shipping is free for the United States, $5 for both Canada and Mexico, and $10 for every other international country. If you wish to customize a perk, email me HERE.STRETCH GOALS: What if you raise over $20,000?Unlike Sunrise Skater Kids, I am the vocalist of Canadian Softball. Because of this happy coincidence, I will literally take the band on a live house show tour if I can get enough money to fund such a thing. If you want to see music videos, merch upgrades or perhaps extra songs, get your friends in on the campaign and help us exceed our stretch goals!

$20,000: Campaign success, album funded!

$30,000: I will take Canadian Softball on a house show tour. Seriously.

$35,000: The house show tour could become a legit venue tour.

$50,000: Guess I'll have to record another album or something.

$100,000: I will eat my own foot and put the video on YouTube.
 BUDGET: Why do you need $20,000?As a relatively low-profile YouTuber, I make a humble income. Doing something like this is more expensive than you would think, and $20,000 is actually a pretty low amount for how much money I'll be forced to dish out. Although I surpassed BOTH budgets for my last two crowdfunding campaigns, I still ran out and used some of my own money (merch fulfillment alone for Friendville was $14,000). Luckily, it all worked out financially and I'm not living on the streets.Remember that your contributions are NOT donations. Every amount starting at $1 gets you perk, so you're essentially just pre-ordering an album or merch. Although production value is very important to me, keep in mind that not all of the $20,000 would be used for actual music production. Here are the things that I need to pay for in order to make this Canadian Softball release happen...

Recording, mixing & mastering: $6,000

Media (artwork, videos, etc.): $1,500

Online distribution & publishing: $250

Perk fulfilment: $5,000 to $10,000

Travel costs: $200 to $400

Indiegogo & PayPal fees: $1,000

Estimated taxes: $2,000 to $4,000

Other potential costs: $500
NOTE: Ultimately, ALL money raised goes back into my music somehow.

 
SUPPORT: How else can I help?Some of you are poor as shit (but somehow still have access to the internet). If you are unable to contribute, you can still help by spreading the word and telling your friends about the campaign. Here are some things you can do...
Tell your friends about Canadian Softball and this new project.
Post the campaign video to Facebook, Twitter and Tumblr.
Like the Canadian Softball page on Facebook.
Subscribe to my YouTube channel. Lots of weird things on there.
Follow me on social media to like/share/retweet my garbage.
Sell drugs and give me a percentage of your profits.
If you have questions about anything that weren't made clear by this page, you can always send me an email HERE.

story: Acoustic guitar and violin duo with members Jeremiah Turner(guitar) and Kevin Grayson(violin), based out of Atlanta, are string musicians who have embraced their calling. Having performed extensively throughout the southeast, it is a mission of theirs to share their music all over the land. Where classical Beethoven/Mozart meets Jim Hendrix/John Mayer with a sprinkle of Outkast. To travel all over the country sharing their music and inspiring others is the imperative purpose of this tour.

To travel all over the country sharing their music and inspiring others is the imperative purpose of this tour.

story:
TheFamilyHarp is the birth of a new season in my life. Through many changes in the last year or so, God has allowed me to learn a few things. The most important, priorities and keeping first things first. Many times we have great motivations and feel like maybe God has called us to do certain things. In some cases, this becomes as important or more important that what we should be keeping near the top of our priority list. For me, I needed to hold my family in a place all its own. I needed to re-position things and make God and family first above everything else. I was created to worship my God and lead my family, and then everything else.

With a repositioning in my life, I am at a place where my family and I are ready to release new music. The purpose is to share what God has put on my heart and to praise Him for it . Because of this, all TheFamilyHarp's music will be free via digital download. This is where I need your help. This album, when done, may be free but the making of it will not be. There is a lot of work that will go into this project. A group of amazing people have signed on to be a part of this project. All of which need to be compensated for their efforts. I can not do this alone. I need your help to help fund TheFamilyHarp's debut album "My Anchor Holds".

story:
Tell us about the songs!

The song selections on Just For Once range in style from adult contemporary to acoustic, from "old school" R&B to "straight ahead" jazz. There are well-known songs "reimagined," some performed just as you would expect them, and underexposed songs that are dear to my heart.   There are songs about the many ways we experience love, about intimacy and connection, about reminiscence, and about celebrating what lasts and really matters.

Who better to sing about those things than someone who's been around the block a few times! 

All kidding aside, these are songs that I have had a deep desire to sing for a long time and that resonate deeply within me. Your financial support of Just For Once will allow me to fulfill my lifelong dream of recording and, in return, give you a captivating musical work that you can enjoy for a lifetime.  

Those of you who know me as a performer have been waiting for me to record for many years, and I can't thank you enough for your continued support and encouragement.  Knowing that I will be able to create this beautiful work for you with such a gifted team is beyond description. 

The Impact of Your Support

Your financial support of Just For Once will allow me to do 5 important things with this recording that I couldn't afford to do on my own:

1.  I'll be able to record in a professional studio with experienced session musicians.

2. I'll be able to have Grammy nominated arranger/pianist John di Martino involved in the entire production and recording process.  John is one of the most sought after accompanists working today, because of his ability to musically "shapeshift" to any style required.  We also have a fantastic working chemistry, so having him as the musical director assures that the arrangements and final production will beautifully reflect my artistic vision.

3.  I will be able to continue my coaching relationship with Claude McKnight, founder and lead tenor of  10 time Grammy award winning vocal group Take 6.  Over the summer, Claude has helped me broaden the scope of my vocal interpretation palette. I'm very pleased with the results and his continued input over the course of the recording will be invaluable.

4.  Graphic designer extraordinaire (and dear friend) Robert Wale will be able to fully invest in creating the CD artwork so that it looks as beautiful on the outside as the music inside.

5.  I will have sufficient funds to include special guest musicians to add the perfect nuances to each song.

The Bottom Line:

I need to raise $3500 to accomplish Phase I of Just For Once.***

Phase I  includes writing the arrangements and rehearsing with John di Martino,  and vocal coaching with Claude McKnight in September/October 2016.

Next, I'll need $6500 for Phase II!

Phase II includes rehearsing and recording with John di Martino and session musicians, rehearsal space rental and recording studio costs

Later, I will need another $10,000 to proceed to Phase II and complete the album

Phase II includes adding guest artists and final vocal dubs, getting the album mixed and mastered, cover art and website design, and the printing of the final product!  But that's another campaign :)

Perks!

I so enjoyed coming up with special ways to say THANK YOU for enabling me to make this recording,  There's a contribution level for EVERY budget!

I'll write a personal thank you note to each of you for helping to make this dream come true. There are autographed photos and CDs, as well as VIP tickets for the CD Release Parties.  Every contribution of $100 or more will be acknowledged in the release event programs.

Those of you who support at the $5000, $10,000 or $20,000 level become "Producers" and receive a very exciting perk! In addition to acknowledgement on the CD cover and a front row table at one of the CD Release Parties, John di Martino and I will come to your home for a private house concert for you and your guests (In CT/NYC area - other locations may require additional travel and/or lodging expenses).

    Risks & Challenges

    The risks and challenges associated with this project are minimal, as we can schedule the recording process around our other commitments and take our time to do it well.  The only challenge is raising sufficient funding to complete the project. 

      Other Ways You Can Help

      There are MANY ways that you can help me realize my dream; all of these are valuable and very much appreciated: 

      • Contribute at whatever level you are able, more than once if you like!
      • "Like" my Facebook fan page "Lisa Marien-Just For Once" and invite your friends to "like" and "share" it as well
      • Email this Indiegogo campaign link to at least 5 people on your personal or professional list
      • Use the Indiegogo share tools found on this page and check back often to see how close I am to reaching my goal!

story:
No matter how much we raise, BAMF is ON.

July 10th, 11th, and 12th at RUOCCO PARK in San Diego. 

Friday & Saturday 10am - 10:30pm & Sunday from 10am - 5pm.

We’re proud and delighted to announce* musical stylings from The Doubleclicks, Paul & Storm, Kirby Krackle, Eben Brooks, Molly Lewis, Random Gibberish, The Library Bards, Allie Goertz, Nerf Herder, Mega Ran, DJ Galactic Ray, and DJ DN3.

As well as comedy from T.J. Chambers, Jen Seamen, Ed Galvez, Joseph Scrimshaw, and more!

And with your support, many more! You can also look forward to quidditch matches, hosted by U.S. Quidditch, and a cosplay contest!

*lineup subject to change

The festival will be open from 10am - 10:30pm on Friday and Saturday, and from 10am - 5pm on Sunday.

Who are we?

We’re a couple of nerds who LOVE Comic-Con. Last year, our greatest SDCC mission was to meet the dudes from Welcome to Night Vale and get a Hannibal Funko doll. (Dr. Lecter slipped through our fingers, alas.) This year, our ambitions are a just a little bigger…

SDCC wouldn’t be SDCC if it weren’t for the veritable Narnia of off-site events. But between the actual tattoos and obstacle courses, we wanted something something for YOU, the con-goer:

Introducing BAMF: the BIG AWESOME MUSIC FESTIVAL

BAMF is an oasis from the nonstop chaos that is Comic-Con. It’s a place to rock out, recharge, and ROFL between panels, parties, and exhibit hall expeditions.

Why do we need your support?

It’s all about that extra mile. We have the space. We have the stage. We have the vendors. We have the artists.  But with your support, we can make it bigger and BAMFIER.

We want to give you more! More artists, more games, a dance party, live streaming, and big rewards! That’s where you come in. The majority of the $75K will go toward talent fees. Apart from that, your support will help cover venue costs, staging, staffing, and equipment.

We started BAMF for you, our fellow SDCC pilgrims who live geek culture and love geek music. And we want to give you what you want. So the more support we get from you, more we can try and bring them to BAMF. This is your festival.

All we ask of you is

1) Support: every little piece counts

2) Spread the word, because more little pieces count even more #BAMF2015

What do you get?

Some boss rewards.

If you contribute just $5 or more, you’ll get a free download of the full version of the official BAMF song, by Eben Brooks.

For a little more you can let people know exactly what a BAMF looks like in our Indiegogo official t-shirt.

You can also buy a spot on a quidditch team for the BAMF quidditch match!

And signed merch from Paul & Storm, The Doubleclicks, Kirby Krackle, Molly Lewis, Eben Brooks, and the rest of our artists.

This is just the beginning; stay tuned for tons more rewards!

story:
We met Brianna at VegasCon 2015 and had so much fun that we want her at every convention we go to! Unfortunately, she lives in Australia, so it's unrealistic that she'd be able to make more than one American con per year. So in her stead, we want to order a life-size cardboard version of Bri to take with us and use in photo ops, selfies, etc. That way she can be at the cons without being at the cons.

The cardboard cutout itself is going to cost us about $180-220 with shipping. So why are we aiming for $500? We want it to be a real as possible, so we want to have outfits, costumes, and props for different days and ops. Ideally, we'd like to get Cardboard Bri signed by as many of the SPNfamily as possible, so extra money would go towards autographs as well. And with a little cushion, we'd also be able to eventually send Cardboard Bri to Real Bri despite pricey shipping costs.

If we hit our goal, we'll announce something special we have planned for Cardboard Bri,but relies on raising more than the initial amount.

Thanks so much,

Katelyn and Sienna


P.S.--You can contact us at cardboardbri2cons@gmail.com or @CardboardBri on twitter for more information.

story:
Short Summary

I've been playing music since I was born, practically. From church toddler's choir at three, to rocking the recorder in 4th grade, and to picking up my first guitar in 6th, music has, and always will be, a staple in my life.  Over the last few years, songwriting has become a serious passion of mine - it is my safe haven. When I am confused, when I am overjoyed, when I am depressed, when I am searching for an answer, or a more clear head about something - I'll start writing. Music helps people heal, and it helps people think - what an amazing thing.

I've compiled fifteen of the dozens of songs I've written over the last couple of years, and it's time to get these recorded, and start making my dreams come to fruition.

The official title of the album is... 

"IN SEARCH OF CERTAINTY"

...and to make this happen, I certainly need your help.

What I Need & What You Get

I need to raise funds to pay for the recording/production of this album. I have the studio space, the time, and an amazing sound engineer that I will be working with to make everything sound great. This money will also go into not only recording the album, but producing physical copies of the album and the artwork, along with other promotional items. 
Listed to the side are perks that come along with your generous donations. Check em' out! 

The Impact

This is my dream - to record and share the music that I pour my heart, mind, and soul into. With your donations, this will be possible!

This is also an extremely opportune time to record this album. I am a rising senior Acting Major at Webster University's Conservatory of Theatre, and will be graduating in 2016. At the end of the year, I will be traveling to New York City and Los Angeles to audition for and meet with casting/talent agents in two of the most booming entertainment cities in the world. With this album under my belt and ready to present to them, who knows who's hands it could get into, and what leap that could make for my career? It's not an easy lifestyle that I'm getting myself into as an Actor/Singer/Songwriter, but it is undeniably what I feel called to do. It has always been my dream and passion - it's time to chase it full force. Your donations will help me do so.

Also, I plan on performing a concert at which all of the proceeds from ticket sales and album purchases will go towards getting my Senior Performance Class of 2016 to Los Angeles. Having this album available for purchase will make this possible!

Risks & Challenges

I'm a broke college student. The only hurdle to get over in this process is the moolah $$$. The songs are written, the studio is ready, and the time is now. I just have to pay for it! 

Other Ways You Can Help

Some people just can't contribute, but that doesn't mean they can't help!

Share this page on social media as often as you can throughout the campaign! Forward it to people who you know may be interested!


Every penny helps, people, and I will be eternally grateful for each and every donation. Also, due to the nature of the PERKS, we could potentially be make some MORE art in the process. That's pretty awesome. 

I will keep you updated on the process of the funding and the recording. I want you all to feel like you're a part of this - and you are with your donations and support. Let's make an album, y'all!

Share this page on social media as often as you can throughout the campaign! Forward it to people who you know may be interested!

Every penny helps, people, and I will be eternally grateful for each and every donation. Also, due to the nature of the PERKS, we could potentially be make some MORE art in the process. That's pretty awesome. 
I will keep you updated on the process of the funding and the recording. I want you all to feel like you're a part of this - and you are with your donations and support. Let's make an album, y'all!

story:
Short Summary

Contributors fund ideas they can be passionate about and to people they trust. Here are some things to do in this section:

Tenor Nathan Granner, a renowned solo and collaborative artist, has a “vibrant and flexible” voice (The Boston Globe) and “possesses utter control of a ravishing mixed head sound.” (Opera News) Mr. Granner uses his voice in a variety of artistic and expressive styles, ranging from opera to jazz and classical cross-over performances. As an opera singer, Mr. Granner has performed as Nemorino in L'elisir d'amore, Ferrando in Cosí fan tutte, and Rodolfo in La Bohéme in performances with Lyric Opera Kansas City, Opera Theater of St. Louis, Tulsa Opera, Wolf Trap and Glimmerglass Opera. In the crossover realm, he is a founding member of The American Tenors, whose Sony Masterworks album reached top five in the classical crossover charts. 

 

  • In the middle of my career I felt the need to go back to school. After graduating from UCLA with my Masters in Music I am in a much better position to
    • work in the field of opera
    • work in the music industry (Film and Television) in the Los Angeles market
  • In order to do that, as an opera singer and as an industry professional I have to work my way (back) in to the these communities
    • auditions (for opera-in New York and abroad, including the EU)
    • coaching (solidly learning the music and language to an exacting standard)
    • materials and marketing (getting the word out that I am available with)
      • headshots
      • biographical material
      • trade magazine, catalogue and social media promotion

This campaign begins the ride to getting on the professional opera stage again. It doesn't happen overnight, but it has to begin somewhere. This is a really great opportunity right out of the gate to work with two great companies and great people.

This for me is a really big deal in getting my name out there for the remainder of this audition season on the national scene. 

I am needing some help getting from Los Angeles to New York. It's Labor Day pricing on the airlines and with transitioning to the Los Angeles area I am challenged to get enough funds to fly.

This particular request is very much a surprise and something of an artistic emergency. I will do a proper campaign in the next month to dig into some really cool things I have planned. 

  • House Concerts
  • Individual Recordings
  • Digital Technology Devices which cannot be mentioned here, but are in prototype stage

All of the funds whether my goal is met or not goes directly to subsidize either paying travel/lodging costs or to pay for coaching and lessons.

The Impact

This is a really important part in my development as an artist. I am at the point where I am singing better than I ever have. If my voice and talent were meant to be on the stage and heard through your speakers and headphones, this would be the time to make it happen.

I've been doing this for a long time now and cannot thank you enough for your previous and your continued support to help my career along in the times when I truly need help the most. Over and over I get people who come up to me or write me and say how much my music has meant to them, or how many times they've played a CD or listened to some of my albums. I truly think there is more and BETTER on the way! I need you now to light that little spark.

While this is all true, I have to say there is risk here. This proposal is for a couple of auditions. There are no guarantees that an audition will lead to an immediate role. What it will do though is put my voice and talent in front of people who have the power to cast and also who are truly leaders in the larger opera community. Maybe not today, but tomorrow the interest will come to a head. Still, I'm very confident in a great showing and the prospects look REALLY GREAT... for this leg and into the near future.

If you cannot help:

Just forward the word along and send folks to the myriad places where my music exists. http://nathangranner.com for example! :)

Also there is a share button. Share with friends whom you think would love to help and would love the music I sing. 

Thank you so very much!!!

 

Nathan-
Nathan Granner
www.nathangranner.com

story:
Hey guys! My name is Kyle Dunn. Growing up on a farm in Kingston, Ontario, I have always had a knack for country music. I released my first EP of seven songs - City Lights - in the summer of 2015. Over the last year, I have been completely blown away by the support of my family, friends, and growing fan base. This past year I was able to open for George Canyon, and this coming summer I will be opening for Doc Walker. You have all helped me along the way, and it's safe to say I wouldn't have these opportunities without you. 

To keep riding this wave, I have a goal to release a second, seven song EP in the fall of 2016. City Lights was only the beginning of the many songs I have been a part of writing over the years, and I'm thrilled that there may be a chance for all of you to not only hear it, but be a part of it. 

What We Need

In order to make the EP from beginning to end, it will cost upwards of $7000. The band and I will be taking our material down to Nashville, Tennessee, where some of the industries best will help us bring our music to life. 

Every dollar we receive will go into the making and production of the EP. Anything above our goal amount will be used to promote the new music, and get it out to radio, and market it on social media. 

What You Get!

I chose this platform to raise money because it also provides the chance to give back to you. With the band, I have come up with different perks for each donation made, ranging from a preorder of the new EP you helped get out there, to a backyard BBQ with the whole band, and even a chance to have your company name and logo on the back of the CD case. There is something for everyone, so check it out and see what suits you best. 

Other Ways You Can Help

If you're not in a position to donate money, you can help us just as much by spreading the word of our band and campaign on social media. You can use the indiegogo share tools to get the band out there and hopefully pique the interest of others.
